   123.01 DIRECTOR OF FINANCE; APPOINTMENT, DUTIES AND BOND.
   (a)   The Director of Finance is to be appointed by the Mayor and shall
serve at the Mayor’s pleasure. The initial appointment to such office shall be
made not earlier than January 1, 1968. (Ord. 52-1967. Passed 12-12-67.)
   (b)   The duties of the Director of Finance shall henceforth be as follows:
      (1)   All duties of the Director as set forth in Section
6.03 of the City Charter;
      (2)   All duties of the Tax Administrator, as set forth in Sections
111.2301 et seq., of the Municipal Income Tax Ordinance; and
      (3)   Ministerial and clerical duties formerly performed by the City’s
Finance Clerk, and such other duties and functions as may be assigned from time
to time by the Mayor or Council.
(Ord. 4-1978. Passed 1-24-78.)
   (c)   The Director who presently also acts as Tax Administrator shall be
required to provide a surety bond in the amount of fifty thousand dollars
($50,000), the premium for which shall be paid by the City. (Ord. 5-1975.
Passed 3-11-75.)
   (d)   The Director of Finance shall also act as the Risk Manager of the
Municipality and shall have the following responsibilities and duties:
      (1)   Maintain an efficient incident reporting and claim handling system.
      (2)   Maintain records and location of all physical properties and their
replacement value when necessary.
      (3)   With other department heads, obtain information on changes in
operating procedures and protective services.
      (4)    Coordinate the risk implications in prospective activities with
the Risk Management Committee.
      (5)    Provide the Risk Management Committee observations and reviews of
loss prevention activities in conjunction with other department heads and
outside specialists.
      (6)    Assist in the establishment and evaluation of a program of loss
control. (Ord. 43-1988. Passed 5-24-88.)
      (7)    Forward immediately upon receipt to the Chairman of the Risk
Management Committee copies of any and all information pertaining to claims or
potential claims against the Municipality or any of its employees or agents.
The Risk Manager shall have no discretion in determining which claim documents
are to be forwarded to the Chairman of the Risk Management Committee; all such
documents shall be forwarded immediately. (Ord. 11-1989. Passed 2-14-89.)
   123.011 ENTERPRISE ZONE COORDINATOR.
   (a)    The Director of Finance shall be the Enterprise Zone Coordinator for
the Municipality.
   (b)    The Enterprise Zone Coordinator shall be the liaison between the
Municipality and all County, State and Federal agencies pertaining to the
Enterprise Zone, shall administer the Enterprise Zone Program and shall be
responsible for all communications and obligations between the City and those
business entities participating in the Enterprise Zone Program. (Ord. 40-1992.
Passed 9-22-92.)
   123.02 TAX ADMINISTRATOR; APPOINTMENT, DUTIES AND BOND.
   (a)    The Mayor shall appoint an Administrator to administer the provisions
of Chapter
111 (Ordinance 61-1966, passed December 27, 1966, the Income Tax Ordinance of
the Municipality), subject to the confirmation by a majority of the members of
Council. The Administrator shall be responsible to the Mayor in the
administration of his duties as Administrator.
   (b)    The Administrator shall be required to provide a surety bond in an
amount fixed by Council, the premium for which shall be paid by the City.
(Ord. 62-1966. Passed 12-27-66.)
   (c)    The Director of Finance shall also serve as Tax Administrator and
shall receive such compensation for acting in such dual capacity as may be
fixed by Council.
(Ord. 4-1974. Passed 1-22-74.)
   123.03 PAYMENT OF EXAMINATION COSTS OF SEX OFFENSE VICTIMS.
   (a)    Payment is hereby authorized for the costs incurred by a hospital or
emergency facility, not otherwise compensated by insurance, for the conducting
of a routine examination of a victim of rape, sexual battery, corruption of a
minor, gross sexual imposition or felonious sexual penetration, conducted in
preparation for the prosecution of such offense.
   (b)    Such moneys are to be paid upon submission of an invoice from the
hospital or emergency facility, and shall be approved by the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 55-1976. Passed 12-14-76.)
   123.04 CREDIT OF INTEREST ON DEPOSITS.
   (a)    The Director of Finance is authorized to invest City funds not
required for immediate use whether such funds be designated active, interim or
inactive, in interest bearing deposits or other forms of investment authorized
by general law for the investment of Municipal funds. Balances belonging to
different funds of the Municipality may be co-mingled for investment purposes,
unless such co-mingling is expressly prohibited by law.
(Ord. 5-1982. Passed 3-9-82.)
   (b)    All interest received on invested moneys of the Municipality, without
regard to the funds, accounts and departments to which the invested moneys may
be attributed, shall be credited to the General Fund.
(Ord. 5-2025. Passed 1-28-25.)
   (c)    Interest received on Federal Revenue Sharing Trust Fund money shall
be recognized and credited to such Fund at the end of each year by a transfer
from the capital improvement fund. The amount transferred to the Federal
Revenue Sharing Trust Fund shall be a percentage of all interest received
during the past year. The percentage shall be determined by comparing the
average monthly balance of the Federal Revenue Sharing Trust Fund with the
average monthly balance of all funds together.
   (d)    The Director shall report to Council, quarterly, the total investment
income received by the City and the manner in which the same has been credited
on the City's books of account. (Ord. 5-1982. Passed 3-9-82.)
   123.05 CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT FUND.
   (a)    The Director of Finance is hereby authorized to create a separate
fund for the City of Highland Heights to be known as the Capital Improvement
Fund.
(Ord. 47-1972. Passed 12-12-72.)
   (b)    The Fund created by subsection (a) hereof shall receive, in addition
to investment income as provided by Section
123.04, one-half of the receipts from the City admission and amusement taxes,
plus any sums allocated by Council from time to time.
(Ord. 59-1978. Passed 10-10-78.)
   (c)    The Capital Improvement Fund, as created by subsection (a) hereof,
shall be used for the purpose of funding new capital improvements within the
corporate limits of the City, and to provide debt service on existing capital
improvement projects.
   (d)    The Director of Finance shall keep an accurate accounting of all
money deposited in the Capital Improvement Fund, and report to Council, from
time to time as requested, as to the status of the Fund. (Ord. 47-1972. Passed
12-12-72.)
   123.06 FEDERAL REVENUE SHARING TRUST FUND.
   (a)    The Director of Finance is hereby authorized to create a separate
financial fund in the City of Highland Heights to be known as the Federal
Revenue Sharing Trust Fund to receive all Federal Revenue Sharing money as may
be allocated to the City of Highland Heights in the future.
   (b)    All money received by the City directly from the Federal government,
or from the State or County, and designated as Federal Revenue Sharing money,
shall be deposited into the Fund created by subsection (a) hereof, and shall be
spent in accordance with the wishes of Council.
   (c)    The Director of Finance shall keep an accurate accounting of all
money deposited in the Federal Revenue Sharing Trust Fund, and report to
Council, from time to time as requested, as to the status of the Fund. (Ord.
48-1972. Passed 11-28-72.)
   123.07 STREET TREE FUND.
   (a)    The Director of Finance is hereby authorized to create a separate
fund for the City to be known as the Street Tree Fund.
   (b)    All fees received by the City for furnishing and planting of trees,
pursuant to Section
1311.23 of the Codified Ordinances, shall be deposited into the Fund created by
subsection (a) hereof, and shall be expended for the furnishing and planting of
trees, as provided in such section, and for such other purposes as may be
provided by Council.
   (c)    The Director of Finance shall keep an accurate accounting of all
money deposited in the Street Tree Fund in relation to each lot for which it
was received and report to Council, from time to time as requested, as to the
status of the Fund.
(Ord. 58-1984. Passed 11-27-84.)
   123.08 MUNICIPAL CENTER FUND.
   (a)    The Director of Finance is hereby directed to establish a fund to be
known as the Municipal Center Fund, the proceeds of which shall be used for the
construction of a Municipal Center.
   (b)    The Director shall place in the Municipal Center Fund a sum equal to
six percent (6%) of the proceeds of the Municipal Income Tax which is collected
by the City. (Ord. 29-1976. Passed 6-15-76.)
   123.09 INFORMANTS FEE AND EVIDENCE FUND.
   (a)    The Director of Finance is hereby authorized to disburse to the Chief
of Police the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) and the Chief is directed to
maintain an Informants Fee and Evidence Fund.
   (b)    The Chief is authorized to disburse funds from the Informants Fee and
Evidence Fund for information or evidence which shall materially assist police
investigations. After such disbursement, the Chief shall prepare a statement of
the date of the disbursement, the amount of the disbursement and the nature of
the information and case being investigated. Such statement shall be signed by
the Chief and countersigned by the Mayor. Upon presentation of this statement
to the Director, a disbursement shall be made to replenish the Informants Fee
and Evidence Fund from the General Fund.
   (c)    As a result of the actions to be taken in accordance with this
section, the Chief shall be charged with the possession of two hundred dollars
($200.00) adjusted by the amount of any unreimbursed disbursement.
(Ord. 44-1977. Passed 7-26-77.)
   123.10 PETTY CASH FUND.
   (a)    In accordance with all requirements by the State of Ohio, the Petty
Cash Fund of the Municipality is hereby increased to three hundred dollars
($300.00) to be disbursed, accounted for and replaced in accordance with all
applicable provisions of Ohio Law.
(Ord. 30-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   (b)    The Petty Cash Fund shall be administered by the administrative
department of the Municipality but shall be for the use of all departments in
the City.
   (c)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to disburse
from the General Fund to the Petty Cash Fund the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00)
to reflect the increase authorized by this section and is further authorized
and directed to replenish such Petty Cash Fund as expenditures are made.
(Ord. 4-1982. Passed 3-9-82.)
   123.101 PETTY CASH FUND - POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   In accordance with all requirements imposed by the State of Ohio, the
Petty Cash Fund - Police Department of the Municipality is hereby created in
the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00) to be disbursed, accounted for and
replaced in accordance with all applicable provisions of Ohio law.
   (b)   The Petty Cash Fund - Police Department shall be administered by the
Chief of Police.
   (c)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to disburse
from the General Fund to the Petty Cash Fund - Police Department the sum of two
hundred dollars ($200.00) and is further authorized and directed to replenish
such Petty Cash Fund - Police Department as expenditures are made. (Ord. 20-
1992. Passed 6-9-92.)
   123.102 PETTY CASH FUND - BUILDING DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   In accordance with all requirements imposed by the State of Ohio, the
Petty Cash Fund - Building Department of the Municipality is hereby created in
the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to be disbursed, accounted for and
replaced in accordance with all applicable provisions of Ohio law.
   (b)   The Petty Cash Fund - Building Department shall be administered by the

   (c)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to disburse

(Ord. 20-1992. Passed 6-9-92.)
   123.103 PETTY CASH FUND - FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   In accordance with all requirements imposed by the State of Ohio, the

Passed 3-24-98.)
   123.11 MUNICIPAL CENTER BOND RETIREMENT FUND.
   (a)   The Finance Director is hereby authorized and directed to create a
fund for the payment of principal and interest on debts relating to the
Municipal Center Construction Project. The revenue for this fund shall be
primarily derived from the portion of the City income tax money collected and
credited to the Municipal Center Fund in a manner necessary to meet debt
service requirements. In addition, interest earned on the proceeds of borrowing
for the Municipal Center Construction Project shall be credited to the
Municipal Center Bond Retirement Fund for debt service requirements.
   (b)   The Finance Director is further authorized and directed to take
whatever steps are necessary in order to have the fund established herein
approved by the Auditor of the State. (Ord. 114-1982. Passed 12-14-82.)
   123.12 HIGHLAND WOODS SUBDIVISION NO. 2, PHASE I FUND.
   (a)   The Director of Finance of the City of Highland Heights, Ohio, is
hereby authorized and directed to establish a special fund, to be known as the
“Highland Woods Subdivision No. 2, Phase I Fund”.
   (b)   All interest earned on proceeds of the note issued for construction of
the required subdivision improvements in Highland Woods Subdivision No. 2,
Phase I shall be credited to the Fund established herein and shall be expended
for the purpose of reducing the cost of the final assessments levied to finance
such improvements.
   (c)   The Director of Finance shall keep an accurate accounting of all money
deposited in the Highland Woods Subdivision No. 2, Phase I Fund and report to
Council, from time-to-time as requested, as to the status of the Fund.
(Ord. 34-1985. Passed 7-9-85.)
   123.13 SICK LEAVE RESERVE FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby created a fund to be known as the Sick Leave Reserve
Fund within the City. The purpose of such Fund shall be for the accumulation of
funds to meet the future liabilities in paying qualified City employees for
accumulated but unused sick leave at the time of their retirement from City
employment in accordance with the applicable provisions of their current pay
benefits ordinance or negotiated labor agreement.
   (b)   The Sick Leave Reserve Fund shall be funded each year from the General
Fund in an amount to be determined by the Mayor and Council with the
recommendation of the Director of Finance. The Mayor and Council may, from
time-to-time, retain the services of an actuary to determine the basis of such
funding when the same is deemed necessary.
   (c)   The Sick Leave Reserve Fund shall be deposited in a separate bank
account with all interest earned thereon credited to such account.
   (d)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to make
application to the Bureau of Inspection of the State of Ohio for approval of
the creation of the Sick Leave Reserve Fund pursuant to Ohio R.C. 5705.12.
(Ord. 9-1986. Passed 3-11-86.)
   123.14 FIRE DAMAGED STRUCTURE; REMOVAL OR REPAIR SECURING FUND.
   The City hereby authorizes the procedure described in Ohio R.C. 3929.86(c)
and (d) to be implemented whereby no insurance company doing business in the
State shall pay a claim of a named insured for fire damage to a structure
located within this City unless there has been full compliance with the
applicable provisions of Ohio R.C. 3929.86. The designated officer for the City
shall be the Director of Finance. The Clerk of Council shall file a certified
copy of this section with the State Superintendent of Insurance.
(Ord. 16-1987. Passed 10-27-87.)
   123.15 BISHOP ROAD FUND.
   (a)    The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to
establish a special fund, to be known as the "Bishop Road Fund".
    (b)    The proceeds of the Note issued in anticipated collection of special
assessments for construction of the improvements on Bishop Road shall be
credited to the Fund established herein.
   (c)    The Director of Finance shall keep an accurate accounting of all
money deposited in the Bishop Road Fund and report to Council, from time-to-
time as requested, as to the status of the Fund. (Res. 1-1987. Passed 1-6-87.)
   123.16 DRUG LAW ENFORCEMENT FUND.
   (a)    A Drug Law Enforcement Fund is hereby created pursuant to Ohio R.C.
2925.03. There shall be deposited into this Fund all drug offense fines and
bond forfeitures from drug related offenses in which the Police Department was
primarily responsible for the arrest and conviction of the offender.
   (b)    Money deposited in the Drug Law Enforcement Fund shall be disbursed
and used only to subsidize the City's drug law enforcement efforts.
(Ord. 33-1992. Passed 7-28-92.)
   123.17 LAW ENFORCEMENT FUND.
   (a)    There is hereby created a Law Enforcement Fund pursuant to Ohio R.C.
2933.43(D)(4), into which shall be deposited the proceeds from the sale of
contraband and/or moneys seized as contraband.
   (b)    Money deposited in the Law Enforcement Fund shall be disbursed and
used for any of the following purposes, and no other purposes:
      (1)    To pay the cost of protracted or complex investigations or
prosecutions;
      (2)    To provide reasonable technical training or expertise;
      (3)    To provide matching funds to obtain federal grants to aid law
enforcement activity;
      (4)    To provide funds for such other law enforcement purposes that
Council determines to be appropriate.
   (c)    Money deposited in or credited to the Law Enforcement Fund shall not
be used to meet the operating costs of the City that are unrelated to law
enforcement.
(Ord. 33-1992. Passed 7-28-92.)
   123.18 LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)    The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to accept
cash, vehicles and other property in accordance with the Contraband Seizure
Forfeiture Act, Ohio R.C. 2933.43; except that any acceptance of real estate by
the Director of Finance shall be subject to approval by action of Council.
   (b)    The Director of Finance is hereby directed to place all cash received
into a Special Law Enforcement Trust Fund to be used solely for the law
enforcement purposes set forth in the contraband statute as it now exists, Ohio
R.C. 2933.43(D)(4) or as it may be amended in the future. Such Fund shall be
separate and apart from all other special funds.
(Ord. 33-1992. Passed 7-28-92.)
   123.19 ABERDEEN BUSINESS PARK FUND.
   (a)   Under Ohio R.C. 5705.12, and subject to the approval of the Bureau of
Inspection and Supervision of Public Offices of the State of Ohio, the Aberdeen
Business Park Fund, formerly known as the Delta Park Fund (402), is hereby
established.
   (b)   The Director of Finance is hereby instructed to forward a certified
copy of this section to the Bureau of Inspection and Supervision of Public
Offices of the State of Ohio for approval of same.
(Ord. 20-2001. Passed 5-8-01.)
   123.20 GENERAL RESERVE FUND.
   (a)   Under Ohio R.C. 5705.12, and subject to the approval of the Bureau of
Inspection and Supervision of Public Offices of the State of Ohio, the General
Reserve Fund, formerly known as the Contingent Reserve Fund (102), is hereby
established.
   (b)   The Director of Finance is hereby instructed to forward a certified
copy of this section to Bureau of Inspection and Supervision of Public Offices
of the State of Ohio for approval of same.
(Ord. 2-2002. Passed 2-26-02.)
   123.21 LOCAL CORONAVIRUS RELIEF FUND.
   A Local Coronavirus Relief Fund (212) is hereby established for revenues and
expenses associated with the Federal CARES Act as required.
(Ord. 18-2020. Passed 6-23-20.)
   123.22 AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN FUND.
   An American Rescue Plan Fund (213) is hereby established for revenues and
expenses associated with the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 as required.
(Ord. 17-2021. Passed 4-27-21.)
CHAPTER 125
Director of Law
125.01    Appointment and duties.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Establishment of office - see CHTR.
6.01
         Appointment powers and duties - see CHTR.
6.02
   125.01 APPOINTMENT AND DUTIES.
   The method of appointment and the duties of the Director of Law shall be as
set forth in Section
6.02 of the Charter.
(Ord. 1-1967. Passed 1-3-67.)
CHAPTER 127
Service Department
127.01   Service Director; appointment, term and work week.
127.02    Director's duties and responsibility.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Establishment of Department - see CHTR.
6.01
   127.01 SERVICE DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT, TERM AND WORK WEEK.
   (a)    The Service Director shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to
confirmation by a majority vote of the members of Council, and he shall serve
at the Mayor's pleasure.
   (b)    The position of Service Director shall be a full-time office and he
shall work a forty-hour work week. (Ord. 56-1966. Passed 12-13-66.)
   127.02 DIRECTOR'S DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITY.
   (a)    The Service Director shall perform the following duties:
      (1)    Supervise the improvement and repair of all Municipal streets,
avenues, lands, wards, market houses, bridges, sidewalks, sewers, drains,
ditches, culverts, streams and watercourses.
      (2)    Supervise the lighting, sprinkling and cleaning of all public
places.
      (3)    Supervise the maintenance and mechanical repair of all Municipally
owned vehicles, with the exception of Fire Department vehicles.
   The maintenance of Municipal buildings shall not be included in the duties
of the Service Director.
   (b)    The Service Director shall be responsible to the Mayor for the
performance of his duties and any purchases of labor or materials shall be
submitted on proper requisition forms to the Mayor or other authorizing
official for signature and a copy thereof shall be submitted to the Safety-
Service Committee.
(Ord. 17-1983. Passed 4-12-83.)
CHAPTER 128
Department of Public Safety
128.01    Created; Director.
128.02    Conflicting ordinances.
   128.01 CREATED; DIRECTOR.
   (a)   The Department of Public Safety is hereby created. The Mayor shall
serve as Director of Public Safety and have all the powers and authority over
the Police, Fire, Service, and Building Departments.
   (b)   The Mayor shall receive such salary and compensation as the Council
determines on a yearly basis. (Ord. 20-2020. Passed 7-28-20.)
   128.02 CONFLICTING ORDINANCES.
   All prior Ordinances inconsistent with this Ordinance in whole or in part
are hereby repealed to the extent necessary to avoid conflict with this
Ordinance.
(Ord. 20-2020. Passed 7-28-20.)
CHAPTER 129
Building Department
129.01    Establishment and appointment of Building Commissioner and Building
Inspector.
129.02   Powers and duties of Building Commissioner and Building Inspector.
129.03   Plumbing Inspector.
129.04   Electrical Inspector.
129.05   Architect - Engineer - Plan Examiner.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Part-time clerical and secretarial help - see ADM.
121.01
         Enforcement of Zoning Code - see P. & Z. Ch.
1105
         Enforcement of Subdivision Regulations - see P. & Z. Ch.
1163
         Building Code - see
PART THIRTEEN
   129.01 ESTABLISHMENT AND APPOINTMENT OF BUILDING COMMISSIONER AND BUILDING
INSPECTOR.
   (a)    There is hereby established the office of full-time Building
Commissioner for the Municipality. The Building Commissioner shall be familiar
with the construction of residential, commercial and public buildings.
   (b)    There is hereby established the office of full-time Building
Inspector for the Municipality. The Building Inspector shall have the same
qualifications as the Building Commissioner.
   (c)    The Building Commissioner and Building Inspector shall be appointed
by the Mayor, subject to the approval by a majority of the members of Council,
and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor. (Ord. 30-1982. Passed 6-8-82.)
   129.02 POWERS AND DUTIES OF BUILDING COMMISSIONER AND BUILDING INSPECTOR.
   (a)    The Building Commissioner shall be in charge of the Building
Department and shall be responsible for the receiving, handling and disposition
of all applications for permits and for the issuance of all permits required by
the various codes and ordinances such as the Zoning Code, Building Code,
Electrical Code, Plumbing Code, Sanitary Code and Subdivision Regulations of
the Municipality.
   (b)    He shall be responsible for the enforcement of all other ordinances,
resolutions and procedures of the Municipality affecting construction,
repairing, remodeling, removal or razing of any structures as well as the use
of any structure or lands within the Municipality.
   (c)    He shall advise and assist the Mayor, Council and other Municipal
officials with reference to his department.
   (d)    He shall be responsible for making all inspections and the keeping of
accurate and complete records of all Building Department activities, the
charging and collecting of all required fees in connection with permits and
immediately upon receipt thereof shall forward same to the Finance Director and
receive a receipt therefor.
   (e)    The Building Commissioner shall assist the County health authorities
in such matters as may be required.
   (f)   The Building Commissioner shall have the power and the duty to halt
any construction, repairing, remodeling, removal or razing of any structure not
being performed in accordance with the ordinances of the Municipality, or for
the use of any structure or lands not being used in accordance with such
ordinances.
   (g)    The Building Commissioner shall be on duty and be available to the
public, at such times as the Mayor may designate and such hours of availability
shall be posted in the City Hall for the benefit of the public.
   (h)    The Building Commissioner shall adopt rules and regulations for the
operation of the Building Department and such rules and regulations shall be
posted and made available to the public.
   (i)    The Building Commissioner shall provide such reports of the
activities of his Department as the Mayor or Council shall from time to time
require.
   (j)    The Building Inspector shall be subordinate to the Building
Commissioner and shall perform such duties as directed by the Building
Commissioner in order to properly conduct the business of the Building
Department. (Ord. 30-1982. Passed 6-8-82.)
   129.03 PLUMBING INSPECTOR.
   (a)    The position of Plumbing Inspector is hereby established for the
City.
   (b)    The duties of such office shall be as follows: the inspection of all
plumbing construction and installations on all structures and buildings other
than one-family and two-family residential dwellings, under the direction of
the Building Commissioner.
(Ord. 21-1969. Passed 5-13-69.)
   (c)    The Mayor shall appoint a qualified Plumbing Inspector to the
position herein established for a term not to exceed one year, and the person
appointed shall serve until his successor is appointed or has qualified or
until he has been removed from office as provided by law. The Mayor shall also
appoint a qualified Assistant Plumbing Inspector for the same term of office,
same duties and same rate of compensation for the position as that of Plumbing
Inspector. The Assistant shall perform the duties of the office when the
Plumbing Inspector is unavailable for duty. (Ord. 48-1969. Passed 10-28-69.)
   129.04 ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR.
   (a)    The position of Electrical Inspector is hereby established for the
City.
   (b)    The duties of such office shall be as follows: the inspection of all
electrical construction and installations on all structures and buildings other
than one-family and two-family residential dwellings, under the direction of
the Building Commissioner.
(Ord. 22-1969. Passed 5-13-69.)
   (c)    The Mayor shall appoint a qualified Electrical Inspector to the
position herein established for a term not to exceed one year, and the
appointed person shall serve until his successor is appointed or has qualified,
or until he has been removed from office as provided by law. The Mayor shall
also appoint a qualified Assistant Electrical Inspector for the same term of
office, same duties and same rate of compensation for the position as that of
the Electrical Inspector. The Assistant shall perform the duties of the office
when the Electrical Inspector is unavailable for duty. (Ord. 49-1969. Passed
10-28-69.)
   129.05 ARCHITECT - ENGINEER - PLAN EXAMINER.
   (a)    The position of Architect - Engineer - Plan Examiner is hereby
established for the Municipality.
   (b)    The duties of such office shall be as follows:
      (1)    Review of architectural and structural drawings and specifications
of all structures and buildings to be constructed in the Municipality other
than one-family and two-family residential dwellings.
      (2)    Review of electrical drawings and specifications.
      (3)    Review of heating, ventilating, air conditioning and plumbing
drawings and specifications on all structures and buildings to be constructed
in the Municipality other than one-family and two-family residential dwellings.
   (c)    The Mayor shall appoint a qualified professional architect to the
position herein established for a term of one year, such appointment to be
subject to confirmation by a majority vote of Council.
   (d)    No person appointed to the position, either on a full or part-time
basis, shall be interested in the profits of a contract, job, work or services
undertaken by the Municipality or any work which requires review, inspection or
approval by the Municipality. In the event a conflict arises under this
section, the Mayor shall appoint an alternate architect, approved by the State,
for the purpose of a specific plan review, as required in subsection (b)
hereof. The alternate shall be compensated at the same rate of compensation as
provided for the regular position of Architect - Engineer - Plan Examiner.
(Ord. 23-1969. Passed 5-13-69.)
   (e)    The rate of compensation of such office shall be as follows:
      (1)    Forty percent (40%) of the total applicable fees as set forth in
the City Building Code, provided that the total applicable fees are not a
result of a plan examination of a tenant or occupant pursuant to Section
1311.031 of the Codified Ordinances.
      (2)    For all plan examinations of tenants or occupants pursuant to
Section
1311.031 the rate of compensation shall be a minimum of one hundred dollars
($100.00) where a plan examination fee of up to two hundred and fifty dollars
($250.00) is charged, and for those plan examinations for which a fee of over
two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) is charged the rate of compensation
shall be forty percent (40%) of the plan examination fee.
(Ord. 17-1977. Passed 4-12-77.)

151
   131.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   Pursuant to the provisions of Charter Section
6.01, there is created a Police Department which consists of a Chief of Police
and such other employees as may be authorized by ordinance of Council.
(Ord. 22-1991. Passed 6-25-91.)
   131.02 PERSONNEL; COMPOSITION.
   (a)   Composition. The Police Department shall be composed of not more than
the number of officers and employees hereinafter set forth:
      1 Chief
      1 Lieutenant
      5 Sergeants
      16 Patrolmen
      1 Administrative Assistant
      1 Communication Specialist
      1 Police Clerk
      4 Dispatchers
      6 Reserve Dispatchers
      10 Reserve Police Officers
      16 Auxiliary Police Officers
   (b)   Temporary Personnel. Within the limitations established by the annual
appropriation ordinance for operation of the Department, the Mayor shall have
the authority to appoint, from time-to-time, such temporary personnel as are
necessary to carry out the duties and responsibilities of the Department.
(Ord. 30-2020. Passed 10-27-20.)
   131.03 POWERS AND DUTIES OF CHIEF.
   The Chief of the Police Department shall be the head of the Police
Department and direct the administration and operations of the Department, and
shall, with the consent and approval of the Mayor, establish such policies,
procedures, and rules and regulations for the administration and operation of
the Department.
   All members of the Department have all powers provided by ordinance and the
laws of the State of Ohio for police officers of cities, and shall exercise the
same in such manner as may be provided by the rules of the Department and the
orders of the Mayor, the Chief of Police, the Lieutenants and Sergeants.
(Ord. 22-1991. Passed 6-25-91.)
   131.04 CHIEF OF POLICE; REQUISITIONS.
   Any purchases of labor or materials by the Chief of Police shall be
submitted on proper requisition forms to the Mayor and a copy thereof shall be
submitted to the Safety Service Committee.
(Ord. 22-1991. Passed 6-25-91.)
   131.05 RESERVE POLICE OFFICERS.
   The position of Reserve Police Officer is hereby established within the
Police Department. The Reserve Police Officer shall be under the management
control of the Chief of Police and the Chief shall establish eligibility
qualifications for members of the Reserve Force with the approval of the Mayor.
The Mayor is hereby authorized to commission such number of men and women in
compliance with this section as is necessary to supplement the regular police
force. Reserve Police Officers are hereby authorized to preserve the peace and
enforce the laws of the State and the City. This authority contemplates that
such officers shall have the right to bear arms and have authority to make
arrests for the commission of misdemeanors. Members of the Reserve Police Force
shall be employed on a part-time basis and are not eligible for participation
in the Police and Firemen's Pension and Disability Fund and shall be in the
unclassified service of the municipality.
(Ord. 22-1991. Passed 6-25-91.)
   131.06 RESERVE POLICE DISPATCHER.
   The position of Reserve Police Dispatcher is hereby established within the
Police Department. Reserve Police Dispatchers shall have the same
responsibility as the Police Dispatchers. The Reserve Police Dispatcher shall
be employed on a part time basis as required by the Chief of Police and shall
be in the unclassified service of the municipality. The Mayor is hereby
authorized to commission such number of men and women in compliance with this
section as necessary to supplement the regular dispatch force.
(Ord. 22-1991. Passed 6-25-91.)
   131.07 AUXILIARY POLICE OFFICERS.
   In the Police Department, there is hereby created a body to be known as the
Auxiliary Police Unit which shall be under the management control of the Chief
of Police. The Mayor is hereby authorized to commission such number of men and
women in compliance with this section as is necessary to supplement the regular
police force. The Chief of Police shall promulgate rules and regulations for
the organization, training, administration, control and duties and conduct of
the unit, subject to the approval of the Mayor. Members of the unit shall
perform such duties and functions as directed by the Chief of Police and the
Mayor.
   Members of the Auxiliary Police Unit are not eligible for participation in
the Police and Firemen's Pension and Disability Fund and shall be in the
unclassified service of the municipality.
(Ord. 22-1991. Passed 6-25-91.)
   131.08 CITY JAIL; USE BY OTHER GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES.
   (a)   There is hereby established a charge of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per day for the use of the City Jail facilities for the housing of prisoners by
other government entities.
   (b)   The City Jail shall be made available to other governmental entities
on an emergency or temporary basis only and shall not be used by such other
entities on a contract or long-term basis.
   (c)   The Chief of Police or any administrative personnel of the Police
Department assigned by him shall keep an accurate record of the use made of the
City jail facilities by any other governmental entity and shall promptly advise
the Director of Finance of the amount due therefor.
   (d)   The Director of Finance shall, promptly upon receipt of notice of the
use of the City Jail and the amount to be charged, issue an invoice to the
governmental entity using the facility. The funds received therefrom shall be
deposited into the General Fund.
(Ord. 22-1991. Passed 6-25-91.)
   131.09 DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY HELD BY THE POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   Any property that has been lost, abandoned, stolen, lawfully seized or
forfeited and which is in the custody of the Police Department, shall be safely
kept pending the time it is no longer needed as evidence and shall thereafter
be disposed of pursuant to the applicable provisions of the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 22-1991. Passed 6-25-91.)
   131.10 EMERGENCY CALLS OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 9.60 and 737.041, as amended, Council hereby
authorizes the Mayor, the Chiefs of the Police and Fire Departments, and the
officers on duty in charge of the Police and Fire Departments, to render the
services of those Departments to other municipalities, townships, counties, or
the State in times of emergency, whether or not the City of Highland Heights
has entered into mutual aid contracts for police or fire services with any of
those political subdivisions or the State. The determination of “times of
emergency” shall be made only by the Mayor, the Chiefs of the Police and Fire
Departments, or the officers on duty in charge of the Police and Fire
Departments, upon a call for emergency police or fire protection services by
the State or another political subdivision of this State.
   (b)   The personnel of the Police and Fire Departments rendering emergency
services to other political subdivisions shall, as provided by State law, be
entitled to all of their usual wages and benefits, shall be covered by Workers’
Compensation, and shall be immune from any liability arising from the
reasonable, good faith rendering of emergency police and fire protection
services. (Ord. 54-1994. Passed 12-13-94.)
   131.11 MEDICAL CARE FOR PRISONERS.
   (a)   As used in this section:
      (1)   “Medical provider” means a physician, hospital, laboratory,
pharmacy, or other health care provider that is not employed by, or under
contract to or with, the City to provide medical services to a person who is
imprisoned in an institution and the person is under the control of, or was
imprisoned at the direction of, or in custody of, the City and/or a law
enforcement officer of the City.
      (2)   “Medically necessary care” means medical care of a non-elective
nature and a person authorized under Chapter 4731 of the Ohio Revised Code to
practice medicine and surgery or osteopathic medicine and surgery determines
that it cannot be postponed until after a person is released from imprisonment
or custody without endangering the person’s life or health.
   (b)   As regards to medical care that a health care provider not employed
by, or under contract with, the City provides to a person who is imprisoned in
an institution under the control of, or who is in the custody of a law
enforcement officer of the City, both of the following apply:
      (1)   The City is not liable for medical care that is not medically
necessary;
      (2)   If the City is found to be liable for medically necessary care, the
City’s liability to pay or reimburse for medical care that is medically
necessary is limited to an amount not exceeding the amount medicaid would pay
for the care provided if medicaid covered the same kind of medically necessary
care. (Ord. 15-2009. Passed 7-28-09.)
   131.12 MAXIMUM HIRING AGE FOR ORIGINAL APPOINTMENT.
   (a)   No person shall be eligible to receive an original appointment to the
Highland Heights Police Department on or after the person’s forty-first
birthday, and no person can be declared disqualified as over age prior to that
time.
   (b)   As set forth in this section, “original appointment” means the police
department candidate has completed all the necessary steps for hiring as
required by the City and/or its Civil Service Commission and the candidate has
an actual hire date prior to becoming forty-one years of age.
   (c)   Any and all ordinance(s) or Civil Service Commission Rule(s) in
conflict with the express provision of this section are hereby superseded.
(Ord. 27-2012. Passed 12-11-12.)

   133.01 COMPOSITION.
   (a)   The Fire Department shall be composed of a Fire Chief and such other
employees as are authorized by Council, to be filled in accordance with the
provisions as set forth in Section
6.05.01 of the Charter.
   (b)   The complement of the Fire Department shall be set at twenty-one,
consisting of the following:
      1 Chief of Fire
      1 Assistant Chief
      4 Lieutenants
      15 Firefighters (Paramedic)
   (c)   In order to qualify for original appointment to the Fire Department of
the City from and after the effective date of this section, an applicant shall
be a certified EMT-P (Paramedic) and shall maintain such certification as a
condition of continuing employment in the Fire Department. Any existing member
of the Fire Department appointed on or after January 1, 1986 shall obtain
certification as an EMT-P (Paramedic) as soon as practicable following the
enactment of this section and shall maintain certification as a condition of
continuing employment in the Fire Department.
   (d)   Within the limitations established by the annual appropriation
ordinance for operation of the Department, the Mayor shall have the authority
to appoint such part-time firefighters as are necessary to carry out the duties
and responsibilities of the Department. The qualifications and duties of the
part-time firefighters shall be determined by the Fire Chief, with a maximum
number of part-time firefighters not to exceed twenty-five.
(Ord. 38-2022. Passed 11-22-22.)
   133.02 WORK WEEK.
   (a)   Fire Chief. The hours of employment for the full-time Fire Chief are
hereby determined to be forty hours per week, the day-to-day hours to be
determined by the Mayor.
   (b)   Firemen. The office of full-time firemen shall be based on fifty-six
hour weekly schedule consisting of rotating hours with a twenty-four hour work
shift and forty-eight hours off.
   (c)   Schedule. The Fire Chief may schedule the appropriate firefighters to
work a forty hour work schedule if necessary. (Ord. 1-1998. Passed 1-27-98.)
   133.03 DUTIES.
   The duties for full-time Fire Chief and full-time firemen are hereby
determined to be those as set forth by the general laws of the State with
respect to the protection of lives and property in the case of fire, and such
other duties as may be set forth by the Mayor.
(Ord. 55-1967. Passed 11-21-67; Ord. 13-1969. Passed 2-25-69.)
   133.04 CHIEF OF FIRE; REQUISITIONS.
   Any purchases of labor or materials by the Chief of Fire shall be submitted
on proper requisition forms to the Mayor and a copy thereof shall be submitted
to the Safety-Service Committee. (Ord. 17-1983. Passed 4-12-83.)
   133.05 AGE REQUIREMENTS; ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS.
   (a)   No person shall be eligible to receive an original appointment as a
firefighter in the Fire Department unless he or she has reached the age of
eighteen.
(Ord. 28-1998. Passed 8-19-98.)
   (b)   (1)   No person shall be eligible to receive an original appointment
to the Highland Heights Fire Department on or after the person’s forty-first
birthday, and no person can be declared disqualified as over age prior to that
time.
      (2)   As set forth in this subsection (b), “original appointment” shall
mean the Fire Department candidate has completed all the necessary steps for
hiring as required by the City and/or its Civil Service Commission and the
candidate has an actual hire date prior to becoming forty-one years of age.
      (3)   Any and all ordinance(s) or Civil Service Commission Rule(s) in
conflict with the express provision of this subsection (b) are hereby
superseded.
         (Ord. 1-2013. 3-12-13.)

   135.01 RECORDING CLERK.
   (a)   The position of Recording Clerk of the Planning and Zoning Commission
is hereby established.
   (b)   The duties of such office shall be as follows: to attend all meetings
of the Commission and keep the minutes thereof; to transcribe the minutes and
keep a record of the official action of the Commission; to record all matters
for the agenda of the Commission; to prepare, post and distribute the agenda;
to type all correspondence for the Commission; to prepare and deliver or cause
to be delivered, notices and other communications ordered by the Commission; to
keep and maintain files for the Commission and for the Building Commissioner in
proper order; to distribute information and other types of communication to all
members of the Commission; to do research deemed necessary by the Commission;
to advise applicants to the Commission on hearing dates and procedures; to
handle such correspondence as the Commission shall determine; and to perform
such other duties as may be required by the Commission.
   (c)   The Commission shall appoint a suitable person to act as Recording
Clerk, subject to the approval of Council. Appointments shall be made annually
commencing in 1977. The Clerk shall serve at the pleasure of the Commission.
(Ord. 56-1976. Passed over veto 1-11-77.)
   135.02 MASTER PLAN.
   (a)   The Mayor and Council of the City of Highland Heights, hereby adopts
the Master Plan 1996 with certain amendments enumerated in subsection (c)
hereof to be used as a guide to future planning and development of the City. It
is understood that by adopting the Master Plan 1996 the Council does not
sustain the Plan in all of its detail.
   (b)   The Council may amend any part of this Plan at any time by a majority
vote. Furthermore, this Master Plan shall be reviewed annually on a rolling
five-year schedule pursuant to Section 6.07 of the Charter.
   (c)   The Mayor and Council approve the Master Plan with the following
amendments: Focus Areas F and G shall be eliminated from the Plan. This shall
include the elimination of pages 5.9, 5.10, 5.11, the top of 5.12, 6.4, 6.5,
6.6 and 7.5. The entire contents of Appendix E shall be eliminated and replaced
by recommendations made by the Master Plan and Capital Improvement Plan
Committee.
(Ord. 9-1996. Passed 4-9-96.)
   135.03 LEGISLATION.
   In addition to the powers and duties conferred upon the Planning and Zoning
Commission in Article VI, Section
6.04.01 of the City Charter, the Commission shall have the power and duty to
consider and recommend approval or disapproval of any appropriate legislation
referred to it for review by the Council President or by a majority of those
members elected to Council. The approval or disapproval of legislation by the
Commission shall be advisory only and shall not alter votes necessary by
Council to enact such legislation.
(Ord. 12-1988. Passed 3-15-88.)

   137.01 SECRETARY.
   (a)   The position of Secretary of the Civil Service Commission is hereby
established.
   (b)   The duties of such office shall be as follows: to attend all the
meetings of the Commission and keep the minutes thereof; to keep in the form of
minutes a record of the official actions of the Commission; to accurately and
properly keep all the records of the Commission; to keep all files in proper
order; to prepare and deliver or cause to be delivered, notices and other
communications ordered by the Commission; to properly furnish appointing
authorities with certified lists; to maintain an official roster; to certify
payrolls; to handle such correspondence as the Commission shall determine; to,
in conjunction with the Chairman, sign all warrants or orders for the payment
of money on behalf of the Commission; to complete the annual report of the
Commission; to arrange for the scheduling of tests for the Commission; to order
and schedule such tests; to assist the Commission in administering and grading
such tests; to inventory all tests; to prepare all Commission forms; to
schedule appearances to Commission meetings; and to perform such other duties
as may be required by the Commission.
   (c)   The Civil Service Commission shall appoint a suitable person to act as
Secretary. Appointments shall be made annually commencing in 1977. The
Secretary shall serve at the pleasure of the Commission.
(Ord. 57-1976. Passed 12-14-76.)
   137.02 NOTICE OF MEETINGS.
   The Secretary shall post on the bulletin board at City Hall the date, time,
location and agenda of meetings of the Civil Service Commission forty-eight
hours before the time of said meeting.
(Ord. 17-1996. Passed 6-25-96.)
CHAPTER 139
Park and Recreation Commission
139.01    Established.
139.02   Members; terms.
139.03   Annual budget.
139.04   Powers and duties.
139.05   Reports to Council.
139.06   Personnel, hiring.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Creation - see CHTR.
6.01
      Conflict of interest - see CHTR.
6.01.01; ADM. Ch.
107
      Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
      Parks and playgrounds - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 755
      Open meetings - see ADM. Ch.
109
      Compensation - see ADM.

      City recreation park rules - see S. & P.S. Ch.
