   139.01 ESTABLISHED.
   A Park and Recreation Commission is hereby established to operate and
recommend fees to Council for the use thereof of parks and playgrounds,
playfields, indoor recreation centers, swimming pools, acquire recreation
equipment and plan and carry out a recreation program for this community. (Ord.
44-1969. Passed 10-28-69.)
   139.02 MEMBERS; TERMS.
   The Park and Recreation Commission shall consist of seven members; six
members shall be residents of this community to be appointed by the Mayor,
subject to approval by Council and the seventh member shall be a member of
Council to be appointed by a majority of Council. All members of the Commission
shall be compensated in accordance with Section
151.19(d). Terms of resident members shall be for two years. The Council
representative shall be appointed annually. Such appointments or reappointments
shall be made at the first Council meeting in January.
(Ord. 48-1985. Passed 12-10-85.)
   139.03 ANNUAL BUDGET.
   The Park and Recreation Commission shall annually submit a budget by the
first day of June to Council, setting forth the Commission's financial
requirements for the ensuing year. The Commission shall not incur any expenses
during the year not included in such budget, unless authorized by Council. If
such budget or any amendment or modification thereof is approved, Council
shall, within the time prescribed by law, budget and appropriate the necessary
funds. Such budgeted funds may only be expended upon the issuance of a voucher
signed by the Chairman of the Commission and the Mayor. All funds collected by
the Commission shall be deposited with the Finance Director. (Ord. 44-1969.
Passed 10-28-69.)
   139.04 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Park and Recreation Commission shall be vested with the authority to
exercise the powers and perform the duties herein provided and shall have the
powers to make its own rules of procedure, with the following limitations:
   (a)    One member of the Commission shall be elected Chairman by the members
thereof, and shall be responsible for the proper administration of its duties.
   (b)    One member of the Commission shall act as Secretary and keep, or
cause to be kept, at the City Hall, a complete record of all meetings of such
Commission, and all transactions handled by such Commission.
   (c)    A quorum of the Commission shall consist of three or more members.
   (d)    Any official action of the Commission shall require the affirmative
vote of three or more members. (Ord. 44-1969. Passed 10-28-69.)
   139.05 REPORTS TO COUNCIL.
   The Park and Recreation Commission shall make periodic reports to Council,
showing in detail all expenditures made by the Commission. The Commission shall
also report annually to Council the activities of the Commission. (Ord. 44-
1969. Passed 10-28-69.)
   139.06 PERSONNEL; HIRING.
   (a)    Following the effective date of this section, the Director of
Recreation shall continue to serve the term of office until such time as the
term is renewed or his successor is appointed and confirmed as provided
hereinafter. Commencing January 1, 1992 and continuing thereafter, the Director
shall be appointed to serve from January 1 through December 31 of each calendar
year, such appointment subject to confirmation by a majority of the members
elected to Council. The Director shall annually submit to the Park and
Recreation Commission a recreation program and shall administer the recreation
program promulgated by the Commission. The duties of the Director shall include
the supervision and operation of public playgrounds, playfields, swimming
pools, other recreation areas and the programs associated with these facilities
that are controlled by the City. The Director shall attend all regularly
scheduled Park and Recreation Commission meetings. Excusal from attendance
shall be by permission of the Chairman only. The Director shall furthermore
enforce the rules and regulations established by the Commission. The Director
shall perform such other duties consistent with the position or as directed by
the Commission or as may be required by ordinance of Council or as directed by
the Mayor. The Director shall attend the first regular Council meeting in
February, April, June, July, October and November of each calendar year for the
purpose of discussing the City park facilities and the park and recreation
programs. The Director shall be provided with such assistants as may be
authorized by Council from time to time. The compensation of the Director shall
be set by Council from time to time.
   (b)    The Park and Recreation Commission shall hire other qualified
personnel to operate the City's recreation program within the limits of the
budget.
(Ord. 39-1991. Passed 3-24-92.)
CHAPTER 140
Mayfield Area Recreation Council
140.01    Perpetuation of original agreement.
140.02   Highland Heights representation.
140.03    Appointments and terms.
140.04    Vacancy.
140.05   Contributions.
   140.01 PERPETUATION OF ORIGINAL AGREEMENT.
   The Mayfield Area Recreation Council is hereby authorized and directed to
prepare and submit to the Council of each member municipality and the Board of
Education an agreement designed to supersede the agreement known as Exhibit "A"
in Ordinance 18-1972. Such agreement shall perpetuate the intent and objectives
of the original agreement known as Exhibit "A" with the express understanding
that each member municipality may determine the method and/or procedures to be
followed in designating its representatives. Such agreement shall be submitted
to the Council of each member municipality and the Mayfield Board of Education
for their approval or rejection thereof. (Ord. 24-1976. Passed 9-28-76.)
   140.02 HIGHLAND HEIGHTS REPRESENTATION.
   Highland Heights representation in the Mayfield Area Recreation Council
shall consist of two representatives and two alternates. One member and one
alternate shall be members of Council to be appointed by a majority of Council
and one member and one alternate shall be citizen residents of the Municipality
to be appointed by the Mayor subject to the approval of a majority of Council.
(Ord. 12-1977. Passed 3-22-77.)
   140.03 APPOINTMENTS AND TERMS.
   Following the effective date of this section, the Mayor and Council shall
proceed to make their respective appointments to the Mayfield Area Recreation
Council. Initial appointments shall be for a term to expire on December 31,
1977. Appointments for all terms subsequent to the term ending on December 31,
1977, shall be for a period of two years.
(Ord. 24-1976. Passed 9-28-76.)
   140.04 VACANCY.
   If a vacancy occurs, a successor shall be appointed for the unexpired
portion of the term in the manner provided in Section
140.02.
(Ord. 24-1976. Passed 9-28-76.)
   140.05 CONTRIBUTIONS.
   No further contributions to the Mayfield Area Recreation Council are
authorized unless approved by this Council.
(Ord. 24-1976. Passed 9-28-76.)
CHAPTER 141
Commission on Aging; a.k.a. Highland Heights Seniors
141.01    Creation, composition and term.
141.02   Compensation.
141.03   Powers and duties.
141.04   Meetings.
141.05   Funds.
141.06   Blood pressure test fee.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Creation - see CHTR.
6.01
         Compensation - see ADM.
151.19
   141.01 CREATION, COMPOSITION AND TERM.
   (a)    There is hereby established in the City, a Commission on Aging also
known as (a.k.a.) Highland Heights Seniors, consisting of seven members.
   (b)   The Commission on Aging a.k.a. Highland Heights Seniors shall be
constituted as follows: the Mayor shall appoint to the Commission six residents
of the Municipality, four of which shall preferably be sixty years of age or
older. Upon the expiration of the current two year terms expiring December 31,
1982, the Mayor shall appoint three members to the Commission to serve a term
of two years and upon the expiration of the current two year terms expiring
December 31, 1983, the Mayor shall appoint three members to the Commission to
serve a term of two years. All subsequent appointments shall likewise be for
terms of two years.
   
   (c)   Council shall elect one of its members to be a voting member of the
Commission to serve a term of one calendar year. The first such Councilmember
so elected shall serve on the Commission for the balance of the calendar year
in which this section becomes effective and thereafter all subsequent
Councilmembers elected shall serve a full one year term.
(Ord. 8-2020. Passed 3-24-20.)
   141.02 COMPENSATION.
   The members of the Commission on Aging a.k.a. Highland Heights Seniors shall
be compensated as provided in Section
151.19. 
(Ord. 8-2020. Passed 3-24-20.)
   141.03 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Commission on Aging a.k.a. Highland Heights Seniors shall serve in an
advisory capacity to Council on all matters relating to aging, and to recommend
programs for the aging resident of the City and the means of implementing such
programs. The Commission may consider and make recommendations in the following
areas of concern relating to the problems of aging, without limitation:
     (a)    Referral Services or Senior Information and Service Center.
      (1)    Job placement.
      (2)    Skills bank.
      (3)    Medicare - Social Security information.
      (4)    Emergency Services.
            (5)    Telephone assurance.
      (b)    Health.
            (1)    Health survey.
            (2)    Health needs defined.
            (3)    Increased or changing of existing services.
            (4)    Voluntary service programs with medical school, etc.
            (5)    Preventive health program.
   (c)    Leisure Time Activities.
            (1)    Trips.
            (2)    Classes.
            (3)    Exercise programs.
            (4)    Social involvement to provide services.
            (5)    Programs (dances, plays, movies, lectures).
            (6)    Recreation.
            (7)    What is happening in Highland Heights.
   (d)    Transportation.
            (1)    Minibus proposal.
            (2)    Define needs (questionnaire).
            (3)    Coordinating of other minibus services.
      (e)    Nutrition.
            (1)    Coordinating food programs.
            (2)    Food stamp program.
            (3)    Hot food (lunches, meals on wheels).
            (4)    Nutrition education.
                  (Ord. 8-2020. Passed 3-24-20.)
   141.04 MEETINGS.
    The Commission on Aging a.k.a. Highland Heights Seniors shall select
meeting dates which are agreeable to a majority of the members of the
Commission. The Commission shall meet no less than six times per year with
additional meetings as required. A quorum of four members shall be present to
conduct the business of any meeting.
(Ord. 8-2020. Passed 3-24-20.)
   141.05 FUNDS.
   The Commission on Aging a.k.a. Highland Heights Seniors shall have
appropriated such funds for its operation as shall be determined from time-to-
time by Council, such funds to be used for the benefit of the City's senior
citizens in accordance with applicable provisions of Ohio law concerning such
expenditures. (Ord. 8-2020. Passed 3-24-20.)
   141.06 BLOOD PRESSURE TEST FEE.
   There is hereby established a fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars
($25.00) per month, to be paid on the first day of each month, to the nurse who
administers the blood pressure tests for the senior citizens of the City.
(Ord. 8-2020. Passed 3-24-20.)
CHAPTER 143
Boxing Commission
143.01    Creation; members; compensation; bond.
143.02   Adoption of State Boxing Commission powers, functions and duties.
143.03   Licenses, permits required; exceptions.
143.04   Boxing Commission powers.
143.05   Promoter's license required; application.
143.06   Conditions for issuance of promoter's license; contents; expiration
   and renewal.
143.07   Photograph and fingerprints to be taken; use.
143.08   Application for permit to conduct boxing match or exhibition; bond.
143.09   Permit to conduct match or exhibition; issuance, conditions and
contents.
143.10   Prohibited activities of promoters; alternative site or substitute
contestants.
143.11   Official's license or participant's or professional boxer's license
required; application.
143.12   Officials' and professional boxers' licenses issuance conditions;
contents; expiration and renewal.
143.13   License or permit fees.
143.14   Medical and life insurance for contestants.
143.15   Physical examinations; withholding purse; limitations on rounds;
gloves.
143.16   Age of participant; gambling; sham matches prohibited.
143.17   Prohibited actions.
143.18   Financial interest in boxer and premises prohibited.
143.19   Advertising and tickets to include price; sale of tickets.
143.20   Tickets sold or issued not to exceed authorized capacity.
143.21   Appointment and payment of officials.
143.22   Inspectors duties and bond; license revocation; withholding and
forfeiture of purse.
143.23   Grounds for disciplinary license action.
143.24   Written report of ticket sales and gross proceeds; tax.
143.25   Failure to file satisfactory report or pay tax.
143.26   Voucher for Boxing Commission expenses; limitation of expenditures.
143.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Admissions tax - see ADM. Ch.
113
   143.01 CREATION; MEMBERS; COMPENSATION; BOND.
   (a)    There is hereby created the Boxing Commission of the City. The
Commission shall consist of three members who shall be appointed by the Mayor,
subject to confirmation by a majority of the members elected to Council and who
shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor subject to the same approval by
Council. To be eligible for appointment a person shall be a qualified elector
of the State of Ohio, shall have been a resident of the State for not less than
five years immediately preceding his appointment and shall be knowledgeable in
boxing. The Mayor shall designate one member as Chairman of the Commission. Two
members shall constitute a quorum and the affirmative vote of two members shall
be necessary for any action taken by the Commission. No vacancy on the
Commission shall impair the authority of the remaining members to exercise all
powers of the Commission.
   (b)    Each member of the Commission shall be compensated at the rate of one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per fight card, plus reimbursement for actual
expenses, which actual expenses for the entire Commission shall not exceed
fifty dollars ($50.00) per event. The Commission may retain the services of a
secretary who shall be compensated at the same rate as the Commission members.
The Finance Director is hereby authorized to make such payments from the funds
accredited to the Commission within the General Fund. 
   (c)   Each member of the Commission, before entering upon his duties, shall
file a surety bond payable to the City in the sum of one thousand dollars
($1,000). Each surety bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance
of the duties of the Commission, executed by a surety company authorized to
transact business in the State of Ohio and shall be filed with the Finance
Director. The bond shall specify that it guarantees the faithful performance of
the person named both as a member of the Commission and, if appointed, then in
the capacity of Inspector as set forth in Section
143.22.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.02 ADOPTION OF STATE BOXING COMMISSION POWERS, FUNCTIONS AND DUTIES.
   Unless otherwise provided, the provisions of Ohio R.C. 3773.31 to 3773.58
and such administrative rules as the State Boxing Commission may now or
hereafter adopt, amend or rescind are hereby incorporated by reference in this
chapter. The Boxing Commission of the City is hereby authorized to exercise
those powers, duties and functions granted to the State Boxing Commission by
such provisions and rules; to levy and collect for payment into the General
Fund to provide for the operation of such City Commission, and the City, those
fees, charges and taxes imposed or allowed by the aforesaid sections or other
fees, charges and taxes which may be imposed or allowed by the City.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.03 LICENSES, PERMITS REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)    No person shall promote, sponsor or conduct any prize fight or public
boxing match or exhibition unless such person is licensed under Section
143.06, secures a permit to conduct a match or exhibition under Section
143.08 and otherwise complies with the provisions of this chapter and Ohio R.C.
3773.31 to 3773.58.
   (b)    No person shall participate in boxing as a referee, judge,
matchmaker, timekeeper or professional boxer, or as a manager, trainer or
second of a professional boxer, except as a second to fewer than three boxers,
unless such person is licensed under Section
143.11 and otherwise complies with the provisions of this chapter and Ohio R.C.
3773.31 to 3773.58.
   (c)    The provisions of this chapter do not apply to any boxing match or
exhibition conducted as part of an interscholastic or intercollegiate athletic
program, or as part of an amateur athletic program sponsored by or under the
supervision of the National Amateur Athletic Union or the American Olympic
Association in which all contestants are amateur boxers or to any boxing match
or exhibition conducted under the supervision or control of the Ohio National
Guard, the State militia or reserve officers' association in which all
contestants are members of the guard, militia or officers association.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.04 BOXING COMMISSION POWERS.
   Consistent with the provisions of Ohio R.C. 3773.31 to 3773.58 and the
administrative rules of the State Boxing Commission now or hereafter adopted,
the Boxing Commission of the City shall make and may amend, alter or repeal
such additional rules no less stringent than those of the aforesaid sections
and administrative rules as it may deem necessary in the public interest to
regulate and control the conditions and conduct of boxing matches. The
Commission shall enforce its own rules and may suspend and/or fine any
promoter, manager or boxer pursuant to its rules.
   Within thirty days after the conclusion of any fight card the Commission
shall make a report to the Mayor of its proceedings pertaining to each such
event.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.05 PROMOTER'S LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   Any person who wishes to conduct a boxing match or exhibition shall apply to
the Boxing Commission for a promoter's license. Each application shall be filed
with the Commission on forms provided by the Commission and shall be
accompanied by a license fee as prescribed in Section
143.13 and by a cash bond, certified check, bank draft or surety bond of not
less than five thousand dollars ($5,000). The applicant shall verify the
application under oath.
   The Commission shall prescribe the form of the application for the
promoter's license. The application shall include the name of the applicant,
the post office address of the applicant, the fingerprints of the person
signing the application and any other information the Commission requires.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.06 CONDITIONS FOR ISSUANCE OF PROMOTER'S LICENSE; CONTENTS; EXPIRATION
AND RENEWAL.
   (a)    Upon the proper filing of an application to conduct boxing matches or
exhibitions, accompanied by the cash bond, certified check, bank draft or
surety bond and the license fee required by Section
143.05, the Boxing Commission shall issue a promoter's license to the applicant
if it finds that the applicant is not in default on any payment, obligation or
debt payable to the City or the State of Ohio under this chapter and Ohio R.C.
3773.31 to 3773.58, is financially responsible and is knowledgeable in the
proper conduct of such matches or exhibitions.
   (b)    Each license issued pursuant to this section shall bear the name of
the licensee, the post office address of the licensee, the date of issue, a
serial number designated by the Commission and signature of the Commission
Chairman.
   (c)    A promoter's license shall expire twelve months after its date of
issuance and shall become invalid on that date unless renewed. A promoter's
license may be renewed upon application to the Commission and upon payment of
the renewal fee prescribed in Section
143.13. The Commission shall renew the license unless it denies the application
for renewal for one or more of the reasons stated in Section
143.21.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.07 PHOTOGRAPH AND FINGERPRINTS TO BE TAKEN; USE.
   (a)    The Boxing Commission shall cause a photograph with identification
and the fingerprints of any person signing the application for a license under
Sections
143.06 or
143.11 to be taken in duplicate. One copy of each such photograph shall be
filed with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and one copy of each shall be
filed with the Commission.
 
   (b)    No fingerprints shall be inspected by any person other than a peace
officer, except on order of a Judge or Justice of a Court of record. The
information obtained by any such fingerprint examination shall be for the use
of the Commission in deciding to grant or withhold a license.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.08 APPLICATION FOR PERMIT TO CONDUCT BOXING MATCH OR EXHIBITION; BOND.
   (a)    Each person who holds a promoter's license issued under Section
143.06 who desires to conduct a boxing match or exhibition where one or more
contestants are to be held shall obtain a permit from the Boxing Commission.
Application for such a permit shall be made in writing and on forms prescribed
by the Commission, shall be filed with the Commission and shall be accompanied
by the permit fee prescribed in Section
143.13.
   (b)    The application for a permit issued under this section shall include
the date and starting time of the match or exhibition, the address of the place
where the match or exhibition is to be held, the name of the contestants and
their seconds, the seating capacity of the building or hall where the
exhibition is to be held, the admission charge or any other charges, the amount
of compensation or the percentage of gate receipts to be paid to each
contestant, the name and address of the applicant and the serial number of the
applicant's promoter's license.
   (c)    The applicant shall deposit with the Commission a cash bond,
certified check, bank draft or surety bond in the amount of five thousand
dollars ($5,000) to guarantee the faithful performance of all conditions
concomitant with the provisions pertaining to the issuance of such permit. The
amount deposited shall be returned to the permit holder no later than seven
days following the completion of the boxing match or exhibition for which it
was issued, less any expenses incurred by the Commission or the City in
securing compliance with the performance standards set forth in this chapter,
including, but not limited to, the provisions of Section
143.22.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.09 PERMIT TO CONDUCT MATCH OR EXHIBITION; ISSUANCE, CONDITIONS AND
CONTENTS.
   (a)    Upon receipt of an application for a permit to hold a boxing match or
exhibition under Section
143.08, the Boxing Commission shall determine if the applicant holds a valid
promoter's license issued pursuant to Section
143.06. The Commission shall also determine if the contestants are evenly and
fairly matched according to skill, experience and weight so as to produce a
fair and sportsmanlike contest, and whether the applicant is financially
responsible and is able to pay to each contestant the compensation or
percentage of the gate receipts named in the application. Prior to the
commencement of any match or exhibition the applicant shall deposit with the
Commission the total compensation or estimated portion of gate receipts to be
paid to the contestants named in the application made pursuant to Section
143.08.
   (b)    If the Commission determines that the applicant has met all of the
requirements specified in subsection (a) hereof, it shall issue the applicant a
permit to conduct the match or exhibition. If the applicant fails to deposit
any compensation or portion of gate receipts required by the Commission before
the first contest of the match or exhibition is held, the Commission may revoke
the permit and order the applicant not to conduct the match described in the
permit.
   (c)    Each permit issued pursuant to this section shall bear the name and
post office address of the applicant, the address of the place where the match
or exhibition is to be held, the date and starting time of the match or
exhibition and a serial number designated by the Commission.
   A permit issued under this section shall allow the permit holder to conduct
only the match or exhibition named in the permit. A permit is not transferable.
In the event that the permit holder has scheduled matches on two successive
days, then one permit may be issued for the two day event and only one
performance bond shall be required.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.10 PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES OF PROMOTERS; ALTERNATIVE SITE OR SUBSTITUTE
CONTESTANTS.
   No person who holds a promoter's license to conduct boxing under Section
143.06 shall:
   (a)    Hold any match or exhibition at any time or place other than that
stated on a permit issued under Section
143.08;
   (b)    Allow any contestant to participate in the match or exhibition unless
he is the licensed boxer named in the application for such permit or a licensed
boxer authorized to compete as a substitute for such a contestant by the
inspector assigned to the facility where the match or exhibition is held for
that match or exhibition;
   (c)    Charge a higher admission price for a match or exhibition than that
stated in the application; or
   (d)    Pay a greater compensation or percentage of the gate receipts to any
contestant than that stated in the application.
   The Boxing Commission, upon application by a holder of a permit under
Section
143.08 may allow the permit holder to hold the match or exhibition for which
the permit was issued at an alternative site that is within the City and that
offers substantially similar seating facilities or allow the permit holder to
substitute contestants or seconds, provided that the substitute contestants are
evenly matched with their opponents in skill, experience and weight.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.11 OFFICIAL'S LICENSE OR PARTICIPANT'S OR PROFESSIONAL BOXER'S LICENSE
REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   Any person who desires to participate in boxing as a referee, judge,
matchmaker, timekeeper or professional boxer, or as a manager, trainer or
second of a professional boxer, except a second to fewer than three boxers,
shall apply for a license from the Boxing Commission. The application shall be
on forms provided by the Commission. Each application shall be accompanied by
the license fee prescribed in Section
143.13. The applicant shall verify the application under oath.
   The Commission shall prescribe the form of the application for a
participant's license. The application shall include the correct and ring or
assumed name of the applicant, the applicant's address, the applicant's date
and place of birth, the applicant's occupation, two sets of the applicant's
fingerprints and a copy of the applicant's win and loss record as a
professional boxer.
   An application for a professional boxer's license shall also include a
certified copy of the results of a physical examination of the applicant that a
licensed physician conducted not more than thirty days prior to the filing of
the application.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.12 OFFICIALS' AND PROFESSIONAL BOXERS' LICENSES ISSUANCE CONDITIONS;
CONTENTS; EXPIRATION AND RENEWAL.
   (a)    Upon the proper filing of an application for a referee's, judge's,
matchmaker's, timekeeper's, manager's, trainer's or second's license and
payment of the applicable license fee, the Boxing Commission shall issue the
license to the applicant if it determines that the applicant is of good moral
character, is not likely to engage in acts detrimental to the fair and honest
conduct of boxing matches or exhibitions and is qualified to hold such a
license by reason of his knowledge and experience.
   (b)    A person shall not be determined to possess the knowledge and
experience necessary to qualify him to hold a referee's license unless all of
the following conditions are met:
      (1)    The person has completed such referee training requirements as the
Commission prescribes by rule;
      (2)    The person possesses such experience requirements as the
Commission prescribes by rule; and
      (3)    The person has obtained a passing grade on an examination
administered by the Commission and designed to test the examinee's knowledge of
the rules of boxing, the Commission's rules applicable to the conduct of boxing
matches and exhibitions and such other aspects of officiating as the Commission
determines appropriate to its determination as to whether the applicant
possesses the qualifications and capabilities to act as a boxing referee.
   The Commission shall issue a certificate to each person who meets the
requirements of subsections (b)(1) through (3) hereof.
   (c)    If upon the proper filing of an application for a professional
boxer's license, the Commission determines that the applicant meets such
qualifications and, in the opinion of the licensed physician who examined the
applicant pursuant to Section
143.11, is physically fit to engage in boxing matches or exhibitions, the
Commission shall issue the license to the applicant.
   (d)    Each license issued pursuant to this section shall bear the correct
name and ring or assumed name of the licensee, the address of the licensee, the
date of issuance, a serial number designated by the Commission and the
signature of the Commission Chairman.
   (e)    A license issued pursuant to this section shall expire twelve months
after its date of issuance unless renewed. Upon application for renewal and
payment of the renewal fee prescribed in Section
143.13 the Commission shall renew the license unless it denies the application
for one or more of the reasons stated in Section
143.22. If the application is for a renewal of a professional boxer's license,
the Commission shall also require the applicant to submit the results of a
physical examination that a licensed physician conducted not more than thirty
days prior to the date of the application.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.13 LICENSE OR PERMIT FEES.
   The Boxing Commission shall charge the following fees:
   (a)    For an application for or renewal of a promoter's license, fifty
dollars ($50.00);
   (b)    For an application for or renewal of a licensed participant in boxing
as a professional boxer, or as a referee, judge, matchmaker, manager,
timekeeper, trainer or second of a professional boxer, ten dollars ($10.00);
   (c)    For a permit to conduct a boxing match or exhibition, ten dollars
($10.00).
   The fees prescribed by this section shall be paid to the Finance Director
who shall deposit the fees in the General Fund for use as provided in this
chapter.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.14 MEDICAL AND LIFE INSURANCE FOR CONTESTANTS.
   No holder of a promoter's license under Section
143.06 shall fail to insure each contestant in a match or exhibition he
conducts for hospital, nursing and medication expenses and for physicians' and
surgeons' services. The amount of such insurance shall not be less than one
thousand dollars ($1,000) and shall be paid to or for the use of a contestant
for any injuries sustained in a contest. No licensee shall fail to provide life
insurance to each contestant. The amount of life insurance shall not be less
than five thousand dollars ($5,000) and shall be paid to the contestant's
estate if the contestant dies as a result of participation in the match or
exhibition.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.15 PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS; WITHHOLDING PURSE; LIMITATIONS ON ROUNDS;
GLOVES.
   (a)    Physical Examinations. Each contestant in a boxing match or
exhibition shall be examined by a licensed physician not more than twelve hours
before entering the ring. Each contestant who has had a previous match or
exhibition on or after the effective date of this section and was knocked out
at that match or exhibition shall present to the examining physician a record
of the physical examination performed at the conclusion of that match or
exhibition. If, after reviewing such record and performing a physical
examination of the contestant a physician determines that the contestant is
physically fit to compete, he shall certify that fact on the contestant's
physical examination form. No physician shall certify a contestant as
physically fit to compete if he determines that the contestant was knocked out
in a contest that took place within the preceding thirty days. No contestant
shall compete in a boxing match or exhibition unless he has been certified as
physically fit in accordance with this section.
   Immediately after the end of a match or exhibition the physician shall
examine each contestant who was knocked out in the match or exhibition, and
record the outcome of the match or exhibition and any physical injuries
sustained by the contestant on the contestant's physical examination form.
   Within twenty-four hours after the match or exhibition the physician shall
mail one copy of the examination report to the Boxing Commission and one copy
to the contestant. The Commission shall furnish blank copies of the examination
report to the physician. The physician shall answer all questions on the form.
The person conducting the match or exhibition shall compensate the physician.
No persons shall conduct such a match or exhibition unless a physician
appointed by the Commission is in attendance.
   (b)    Rounds. No holder of a promoter's license shall conduct a boxing
match or exhibition that exceeds fifteen rounds. Each round shall be not more
than three minutes in length. A period of at least one minute, during which no
boxing or sparring takes place, shall occur between rounds.
   No holder of a promoter's license or a permit issued under Section
143.08 shall allow a professional boxer to participate in more than fifteen
rounds of boxing within a period of seventy-two consecutive hours. The
Commission may, for any match or exhibition or for a class of contestants,
limit the number of rounds within the maximum of fifteen rounds.
   (c)    Referees; Withholding Purse. No person shall conduct a boxing match
or exhibition unless a licensed referee appointed by the Commission and paid by
the person is present. The referee shall direct and control the match or
exhibition. Before each match or exhibition the referee shall obtain from each
contestant the name of his chief second and shall hold the chief second
responsible for the conduct of any assistant seconds during the match or
exhibition. The referee may declare a prize, remuneration or purse, or any part
thereof to which a contestant is otherwise entitled withheld, if, in his
judgment, the contestant is not competing or did not compete honestly. A
contestant may appeal the referee's decision in a hearing before the Commission
conducted in accordance with Section
143.22.
   (d)    Judges. No person shall hold or conduct a boxing match or exhibition
unless three licensed judges appointed by the Commission and paid by the person
are present. Each judge shall render a decision at the end of each match or
exhibition. The judges shall determine the outcome of the match or exhibition
and their decision shall be final.
   (e)    Gloves. Each contestant shall wear gloves weighing not less than six
ounces during a boxing match or exhibition. (Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.16 AGE OF PARTICIPANT; GAMBLING; SHAM MATCHES PROHIBITED.
   No person who sponsors, promotes or conducts a boxing match or exhibition
shall:
   (a)    Knowingly permit a person less than eighteen years of age to
participate in the match or exhibition unless neither contestant is a
professional boxer;
   (b)    Knowingly permit gambling, betting or wagering on the result of a
contingency in connection with the match or exhibition; or
   (c)    Knowingly conduct or allow to be conducted a sham or fake match or
exhibition.
      (Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.17 PROHIBITED ACTIONS.
   No person shall:
   (a)    Violate any provision of this chapter or any provision of Ohio R.C.
3773.31 to 3773.58 or any rule of the State or local Boxing Commission;
   (b)    Gamble, bet or wage on the result of a contingency connected with a
boxing match or exhibition;
   (c)    Participate in a sham or fake boxing match or exhibition that is
conducted by a holder of a promoter's license issued under Section
143.06; or
   (d)    Participate in a boxing match or exhibition if he is under eighteen
years of age unless neither contestant in the match or exhibition is a
professional boxer.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.18 FINANCIAL INTEREST IN BOXER AND PREMISES PROHIBITED.
   No person shall have any financial interest in a boxer competing on premises
owned or leased by the person or in which the person is otherwise financially
interested.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.19 ADVERTISING AND TICKETS TO INCLUDE PRICE; SALE OF TICKETS.
   Each person who conducts a boxing match or exhibition shall cause to be
inserted into each advertisement of the match or exhibition the price of
admission.
   Each ticket of admission to any such match or exhibition shall clearly bear
the purchase price. No person shall sell such a ticket for a price greater than
that printed thereon. No ticket shall be sold except from the box office on the
premises in which the match or exhibition is held or such additional locations
as the Boxing Commission has authorized in writing as locations from which
tickets may be sold for a designated match or exhibition.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.20 TICKETS SOLD OR ISSUED NOT TO EXCEED AUTHORIZED CAPACITY.
   No person licensed under Section
143.06 and issued a permit under Section
143.08 shall sell and issue or cause to be sold or issued more tickets or
invitations or admissions to a boxing match or exhibition than, or admit to
such match or exhibition a number of persons that exceeds, the authorized
capacity of the facility or that part of the facility used for the match or
exhibition. This limitation on the number of tickets extends to the issuance of
complimentary tickets and free passes.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.21 APPOINTMENT AND PAYMENT OF OFFICIALS.
   The Boxing Commission shall appoint from among licensed referees,
physicians, matchmakers, timekeepers and judges the officials for boxing
matches and exhibitions held under this chapter. These officials shall be
compensated by the person conducting the match or exhibition.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.22 INSPECTORS DUTIES AND BOND; LICENSE REVOCATION; WITHHOLDING AND
FORFEITURE OF PURSE.
   The Boxing Commission shall employ inspectors to attend each boxing match or
exhibition held under a permit issued under Section
143.08. Only one inspector shall be assigned to any one facility for any one
match or exhibition. Any member of the Commission may act as an inspector, and
when acting as an inspector shall be paid as provided in this section.
   The inspector shall monitor the sales of tickets from the premises box
office on the day of the match or exhibition and, immediately following the
counting of the gross proceeds, obtain a box office statement from the person
conducting the match or exhibitor and mail it to the Commission. The inspector
shall have complete access to any books, records and papers pertaining to the
match or exhibition.
   The inspector shall give bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000)
with sufficient sureties to be approved by and made payable to the Finance
Director. If the inspector appointed for any match or exhibition is a member of
the Commission and has already posted a bond in accordance with Section
143.01 then such member need not file any additional bond under the terms of
this section. The inspector shall receive the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00)
plus his actual and necessary travel expenses, for attending a match or
exhibition which fee shall be charged to the holder of the permit for such
match or exhibition.
   The inspector may order a prize, remuneration, purse or any part thereof
withheld from a contestant if the inspector believes the contestant did not
compete to the best of his ability. The inspector shall file any charges with
the Commission which shall hold a hearing pursuant to the applicable provisions
of the Ohio Revised Code and issue a final order within thirty days after the
inspector files charges.
   If the Commission finds that the contestant did not compete to the best of
his ability it may revoke the contestant's license. When a license is so
revoked, any prize, remuneration, purse or part thereof that the contestant
otherwise would have received shall be paid to the Commission and shall become
the property of the City. (Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.23 GROUNDS FOR DISCIPLINARY LICENSE ACTION.
   The Boxing Commission may revoke, suspend or refuse to renew any license
issued under this chapter if the licensee:
   (a)    Has committed an act detrimental to boxing or to the public interest,
convenience or necessity;
   (b)    Is associating or consorting with any person who has been convicted
of a crime;
   (c)    Is or has been consorting with bookmakers or gamblers, or has engaged
in similar pursuits;
   (d)    Is financially irresponsible;
   (e)    Has been found guilty of any fraud or misrepresentation in connection
with boxing;
   (f)    Has violated any law with respect to boxing or any rule or order of
the Commission;
   (g)    Has engaged in any other activity that the Commission determines is
detrimental to boxing. (Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.24 WRITTEN REPORT OF TICKET SALES AND GROSS PROCEEDS; TAX.
   (a)    No person who conducts a match or exhibition to which the provisions
of this chapter apply shall fail to mail to the Boxing Commission a written
report that shows the number of tickets sold for the match or exhibition and
the amount of gross proceeds within twenty-four hours after the determination
of the outcome of the match or exhibition. The person shall pay to the
Commission a tax of five percent (5%) of the gross proceeds from the sale of
tickets to the match or exhibition, such sum not to exceed five thousand
dollars ($5,000). Such amount shall be paid to the Commission within seven days
following completion of the match or exhibition. The tax imposed by this
section shall be in addition to the admissions tax imposed by Chapter
113.
   (b)    Such taxes shall be levied for the purpose of providing operating
funds for the Commission and any excess shall be deposited in the General Fund
for use by the City.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.25 FAILURE TO FILE SATISFACTORY REPORT OR PAY TAX.
   If any person fails to make a report relating to a match or exhibition
required under this chapter, or files a report under Section
143.22 that the Boxing Commission finds unsatisfactory, the Commission may
examine or cause to be examined the books and records of such person. The
Commission may also subpoena and examine under oath any persons to determine
the amount of gross proceeds for a match or exhibition and the amount of tax
due.
   If a person who conducts a match or exhibition pursuant to this chapter does
not pay the tax due on or before the date prescribed herein he shall pay
interest on the amount of tax due at a rate of five percent (5%) per month up
to a maximum of twenty-five percent (25%). The Commission shall send a notice
of delinquency to such a taxpayer. A delinquent taxpayer may be disqualified
from receiving a new license.
   If a delinquent taxpayer does not pay the tax due and the interest thereon
within twenty days after the notice of delinquency was mailed, he is in default
on such taxes and interest. Any expenses incurred by the Commission in making
examinations of the books and records of a taxpayer who is in default on such
taxes and interest for a period of twenty days after the default occurred shall
be paid by the taxpayer. The Director of Law shall institute suit upon the bond
filed pursuant to Section
143.05 by a person who has defaulted on such taxes, interest and expenses in
order to recover such taxes, interest and expenses.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.26 VOUCHER FOR BOXING COMMISSION EXPENSES; LIMITATION OF EXPENDITURES.
   The Finance Director shall issue warrants for expenses incurred by members
of the Boxing Commission upon the presentation of itemized vouchers signed by
the Chairman of the Commission and approved by the Mayor.
   The total amount of expenditures for the Commission, including compensation
for members of the Commission, the secretary and expenses of the Commission, in
any one year shall not exceed the amount of taxes, license fees and permit fees
collected pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
   143.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord. 44-1982. Passed 6-17-82.)
CHAPTER 145
Highland Heights Home Days
145.01    Authority.
145.02    Composition and appointment.
145.03    Term of appointees.
145.04    Records, actions and meetings.
145.05    Powers of Committee.
145.06    Powers of Committee Chairman.
145.07    Final report to Council.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Community Park - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
921
   145.01 AUTHORITY.
   An annual Highland Heights Home Days shall be celebrated within the City
under the supervision and direction of a Highland Heights Home Days Committee,
to be constituted as herein provided. (Ord. 8-1990. Passed 3-20-90.)
   145.02 COMPOSITION AND APPOINTMENT.
   A Highland Heights Home Days Committee composed of eleven members shall be
appointed annually. The Chairman of the Committee is to be appointed by the
Mayor on or before September 1 of the year prior to which the home days are
celebrated, such appointee to be either a resident or an employee of Highland
Heights. The Chairman shall appoint nine members of the Committee, all of whom
shall be residents of Highland Heights. Council shall select one of its members
as the voting Council representative. Vacancies existing in the Committee from
time to time may be filled by appointment of the Chairman except that Council
shall fill any vacancy for its representative.
(Ord. 41-1993. Passed 9-7-93.)
   145.03 TERM OF APPOINTEES.
   Each annual Highland Heights Home Days Committee shall serve from the time
of the initial appointment of its members until the annual Highland Heights
Home Days celebration and all related business has been completed and a final
report of the Committee's activities rendered to Council. (Ord. 8-1990. Passed
3-20-90.)
   145.04 RECORDS, ACTIONS AND MEETINGS.
   The Highland Heights Home Days Committee shall keep written records of its
official actions and proceedings. Official actions of the Committee may be
taken either by majority vote at a duly convened meeting of its members, at
which a quorum of six or more members is present, or by unanimous written
action, signed by all members. Notice of all meetings of the Committee shall be
given to all members, verbally or in writing.
(Ord. 8-1990. Passed 3-20-90.)
   145.05 POWERS OF COMMITTEE.
   The Highland Heights Home Days Committee shall exercise the following
powers:
   (a)    To select the date of the annual Highland Heights Home Days
celebration.
   (b)    To select the site of such celebration.
   (c)    To arrange for amusements, to be made available to the public at such
celebration.
   (d)    To allocate the physical space available at the celebration site for
such purposes as the Committee may deem appropriate.
   (e)    To arrange for the location of booths, exhibits, refreshment stands,
retail sale outlets, and the like to be used and occupied as a part of such
celebration by individuals and organizations, private, public and civic, and to
enter into agreements with the users or occupiers of such facilities for the
payment of such consideration, if any, as the Committee may deem appropriate
for such use and occupancy. The use and occupation of the particular facilities
of baseball diamonds, swimming pools, and tennis courts are subject to approval
by the Park and Recreation Commission.
   (f)    To expend such funds as may be appropriated by Council to the use of
the Committee, in order to promote the Highland Heights Home Days celebration
and in order to conduct such activities and provide such public amusements as
the Committee may deem proper.
   (g)    To enter into contracts and agreements, of every nature and
description, as may be necessary and proper in that the Committee may not bind
or obligate itself, its members, the City or the Council to the payment of any
sum of money above and beyond the sums previously appropriated by Council to
the use of the Committee.
      (Ord. 2-1995. Passed 2-14-95.)
   145.06 POWERS OF COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN.
   The Chairman of the Highland Heights Home Days Committee shall exercise the
following powers:
   (a)    To call all meetings of the Committee and to circulate written
actions among the members of the Committee for their approval.
   (b)    To appoint such subcommittees as he may desire for such specific
purposes as he may deem appropriate.
   (c)    To preside over all meetings of the Committee.
   (d)    To exercise general supervisory authority over the functions of all
sub-committees during the intervals between meetings of the Committee.
      (Ord. 8-1990. Passed 3-20-90.)
   145.07 FINAL REPORT TO COUNCIL.
   The Highland Heights Home Days Committee shall render to Council a final
report of its activities in writing. Such report shall include the summary
description of the Highland Heights Home Days celebration conducted under the
auspices of the Committee and a complete accounting of all funds received and
disbursed by the Committee, including the funds appropriated by Council to the
use of the Committee.
(Ord. 8-1990. Passed 3-20-90.)
