CROSS REFERENCES
         State law provisions - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1509
         Oil and gas drilling - see OAC Ch. 1501:9-1, 1501:9-9
         Plugging of wells - see OAC Ch. 1501:9-11
   733.01 DEFINITION.
   "Abandoned gas or oil well" as used in this chapter means any gas or oil
well on which production and/or use has ceased for at least one year.
(Ord. 46-1987. Passed 11-24-87.)
   733.02 DRILLING OF OIL AND GAS WELLS .
   The drilling of oil and gas wells in the City for any purpose is hereby
permitted but only as specifically provided herein.
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.03 TYPES OF WELLS REQUIRED TO BE PLUGGED.
   Gas or oil wells, including, but not limited to, the following, must be
plugged:
   (a)    All wells under parking lots, or under streets, roads, highways or
rights of way;
   (b)    Wells located within 200 feet of proposed construction of a new
building;
   (c)    Wells located within the geographic confines of a new subdivision;
   (d)    Any water wells that are or were used in conjunction with the
operation of a gas or oil well; and
   (e)    Any well which is deemed unsafe, hazardous or a nuisance by the Fire
Chief. (Ord. 46-1987. Passed 11-24-87.)
   733.04 PLUGGING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall plug a gas or oil well within the City without first
securing a plugging permit to do so. For each well to be plugged, an
application for a plugging permit shall be made to the Building Department. No
plugging permit shall be issued until it has been approved in writing by both
the Building Commissioner and Fire Chief. The permit fee shall be twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) per well.
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.05 PLOT PLAN REQUIRED TO PLUG AN OIL OR GAS WELL.
   Every person who makes an application for a permit to plug a gas or oil well
shall submit a plot plan by a licensed surveyor, showing thereon the exact
location of the well to be plugged. Such plan shall remain on file with the
Building Commissioner, with a copy to be filed with the Fire Chief. (Ord. 16-
2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.06 PLUGGING REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    All abandoned gas or oil wells required to be plugged by Section
733.03 shall be plugged in a manner prescribed by the Ohio Department of
Natural Resources, Division of Oil and Gas, applicable provisions of the Ohio
Revised Code and this chapter.
   (b)    In addition to requirements set forth by the Ohio Department of
Natural Resources, the following shall be required:
      (1)    All wells to be plugged which are located under parking lots,
roads, streets or other areas to be used for public purposes, shall be enclosed
in a brick or masonry manhole fitted with a steel cover not less than thirty
inches in diameter. Such cover shall be plainly marked, "Abandoned Gas Well"
and shall be used for access for inspection of the well.
      (2)    All plugged wells shall be vented by a vent pipe not less than two
inches in diameter and of such height as prescribed by the Department of
Natural Resources, the State of Ohio and the City Fire Chief and the Building
Commissioner. Such vent pipe shall have a drilled and tapped inspection hold
with hole plug not less than one-half inch in diameter and not more than four
feet above grade.
      (3)    It shall be the duty of the person, in the drilling of a well or
the cleaning of an abandoned well preparatory to the plugging of such abandoned
well, to provide for a drilling-in control gate, which shall be so constructed
as to effectually cut off the flow of gas to the top of the well and which can
be operated at a remote point from the well.
         (Ord. 46-1987. Passed 11-24-87.)
   733.07 DISCOVERY OF ABANDONED WELL.
   (a)    Any person being the owner or lessee of land, who discovers an
abandoned gas or oil well, shall immediately notify the Fire Chief and the
Building Commissioner.
   (b)    Any person who discovers an abandoned gas or oil well during the
development of any land or the construction of any building shall immediately
cease all operations until notification is given to the Building Commissioner
and the Fire Chief and such well is treated in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter.
   (c)    No person engaged in any phase of construction shall remove any
casing or piping of any abandoned well until such well has been reported to the
Building Commissioner and the Fire Chief and to the representative of the
Department of Natural Resources. No construction shall take place either over
or near an abandoned gas or oil well until such well has been inspected and the
recommended type of treatment has been made by the Fire Chief in conformity
with the laws of the State of Ohio and the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 46-1987. Passed 11-24-87.)
   733.08 VENT PIPE REQUIREMENTS.
   All vent pipes over gas and oil wells shall be maintained to the
specifications set forth in Section
733.06(b)(2).
(Ord. 46-1987. Passed 11-24-87.)
   733.09 PRESCRIBING METHODS WHERE PROVISIONS INEFFECTIVE.
   If the provisions of this chapter cannot be applied, or if applied would be
ineffective in carrying out the protection which this chapter is meant to give,
then the Building Commissioner, the Fire Chief and the Ohio Department of
Natural Resources may designate the method to be used.
(Ord. 46-1987. Passed 11-24-87.)
   733.10 RELATIONSHIP TO STATE OIL AND GAS WELLS.
   The City’s adoption of these regulations shall be supplementary to and read
in conjunction with the standards and regulations in Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509 as
they relate to the drilling, constructing, reopening, converting, plugging
back, plugging, operating, maintaining and abandoning of any oil or gas well
within the limits of the City. Whenever the requirements are at variance with
the requirements of the aforementioned Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509, the most
restrictive or that imposing the higher standard shall govern.
   (a)   State Authorization and Filing Permits, Plan, Etc.
      (1)   No person, firm or corporation shall, within the limits of the
City, drill a new oil or gas well or drill into the City from a surface
location outside the City limits, drill an existing oil or gas well any deeper,
reopen an oil or gas well, convert an oil or gas well to any other use other
than its original purpose or plug back an oil or gas well to a source of supply
different from the existing pool, without first having obtained a permit to do
so from the Chief of the Division of Oil and Gas of the State Department of
Natural Resources, pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509.
      (2)   An exact and complete copy of the permit referred to in the
preceding paragraph, along with an exact and complete copy of any application,
plan, map and other documentation filed therefor with the Chief of the Division
of Oil and Gas of the State Department of Natural Resources shall be filed with
the Building Commissioner at least five full business days prior to the
commencement of any drilling, reopening, converting or plugging back as
referred to in the preceding paragraph.
   (b)   City Authorization.  
      (1)   No person, firm or corporation shall within the limits of the City,
drill a new oil or gas well, drill an existing oil or gas well any deeper,
reopen an oil or gas well, convert an oil or gas well to any use other than its
original purpose or plug back an oil or gas well to a source of supply
different from the existing pool, without first having obtained a permit that
is, a "City permit", to do so issued from the Building Commissioner.
      (2)   No person, firm or corporation shall drill into the City from a
surface location outside the City limits, drill a new oil or gas well, drill an
existing oil or gas well any deeper, reopen an oil and gas well, convert an oil
or gas well to any other use other than its original purpose, or plug back an
oil or gas well to a source of supply different from the existing pool, without
first obtaining a registration permit issued by the Building Commissioner.
      (3)   The Building Commissioner may issue such permit to any person, firm
or corporation who has been issued a corresponding permit by the Chief of the
Division of Oil and Gas of the State Department of Natural Resources, pursuant
to Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509 and who has otherwise complied with the applicable
requirements of this chapter. No person, firm or corporation shall be issued
such a City permit until the fee of two thousand five hundred dollars
($2,500.00) has been paid to the City.
      (4)   When the surface location of a gas or oil well is outside the
corporate limits of the City, but enters or terminates inside the City limits,
no person, firm or corporation shall be issued a registration permit until the
fee of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) has been paid to the City.
      (5)   The following information shall be included when applying to drill
or re- enter a well for gas, oil or other hydrocarbon within the corporate
limits of the City.
         (Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.11 STANDARDS AND REGULATIONS FOR DRILLING AND EXPLORATION.
   (a)   Person, as used in this chapter means and includes any person, firm,
partnership, association, corporation, trust, cooperative or other type of
organization. The word "Well," as used in this chapter, means any hole or bore
to any depth, for the purpose of producing and recovering any oil and/or gas.
      (1)   No person shall drill a new gas or oil well within the City without
first securing a permit to do so. For each well to be drilled an application
for a permit shall be made to the Building Commission upon such forms as it may
prescribe. It shall be signed by the applicant or by a person authorized to
sign on the applicant's behalf. In addition, a fee for such permit in the
amount of two thousand five dollars ($2,500.00) shall be paid with any such
application. Said application shall be submitted to the Planning and Zoning
Commission, which shall review the application and recommend to Council what
action should be taken regarding the application. No applicant shall request a
permit to drill more than one well.
      (2)   Contents of permit application.
         A.   The applicant shall submit the information described herein on
such forms as the Planning and Zoning Commission may determine.
         B.   Said application shall be submitted to the Planning and Zoning
Commission, which shall review the application and recommend to Council what
action should be taken on the application.
         C.   The following information shall be included in every application
for a permit to drill or re-enter a well for gas, oil, or other hydrocarbon
within the corporate limits of the City.
            1.    Permit. Each application shall include a complete copy of the
valid permit or permits issued by the State of Ohio for the well to be drilled.
Said copy shall include the plan approved by the state for the disposal and
storage of brine and other waste substances resulting, obtained, or produced in
connection with exploration, drilling, or production of oil or gas.
            2.    Plot plan. Each application shall include a plot plan of the
property involved in the application. The applicant shall develop the property
in accordance with the plot plan. The plot plan shall have thereon:
               a.   North arrow;
               b.   Names, addresses, and telephone numbers of record owner of
property, applicant, and driller;
               c.   Lot lines of all abutting properties as well as the lot
lines of all properties within 500 feet of the proposed well site;
               d.   Location of all buildings, structures and public roads
within a radius of 500 feet of the proposed well site;
               e.   Location of all existing and/or permitted oil or gas wells
and well appurtenances, that is, the well head, piping valves, tanks, tank
batteries, sales lines, and separators;
               f.   Location of all private access roads and driveways to all
well sites and tank sites showing the width of such private roads and
driveways, and such other information as is required below;
               g.   Circles drawn on the plot plan at radii of 100 feet, 200
feet, and 500 feet from the proposed well site;
               h.   The names and addresses of the owners of all properties
shown on the plot plan, including the well site parcel;
               i.   Location of all existing streams, ponds, lakes, and other
surface water bodies, including wetlands, within 500 feet of the proposed well
site;
               j.   Locations of all pipelines from the well site or wells to
tanks or tank batteries and of all pipelines from tanks to existing or new
supply line or lines;
               k.   Location of public and private utilities and easements
within the lease area; and
               l.   City-wide vicinity map at a scale of 1" = 2,000', that
shows the relationship of the proposed oil or gas well site to the surrounding
area and that identifies the location of nearby public streets, public parks,
schools and public buildings within this surrounding area.
            3.   Brine hauler. The application shall include the names,
addresses, phone numbers and division registration number of each person who
has been or will be contracted to haul brine, salt water or other waste from
the well site.
            4.   Emergency Information. The application shall include an
affidavit indicating that the petitioner will comply with the emergency
information of Highland Heights Chapter
1521.
            5.   Site. The applicant shall submit an affidavit satisfactory to
the City confirming written notification of the applicant's name, address, and
phone number; location of the proposed well head drilling unit, and tanks
boundary to all land owners within 500 feet of the well head as well as the
applicant's intention to drill such a well and to make application for a permit
to do so.
      (3)   Fencing and landscaping. The petitioner shall submit a restoration,
fencing and planting plan to the Building Department and, this plan is to be
subject to its approval. All oil and gas well heads, storage tanks and
separator units shall be fenced. In addition, all equipment relating to the gas
or oil well site shall be properly landscaped as approved by the City to
obscure its view from adjoining property owners. The impact on the adjoining
properties shall be considered in the landscape plan. Said landscaping may be
in the form of "recessing" or "earthen diking" of the equipment and,
additionally, pines and/or shrubs shall be planted and maintained in a
surrounding fashion.
      (4)   Insurance/liability. 
         A.   The petitioner shall submit a sworn statement that the owner has
obtained and shall keep in full force and effect during the entire operation of
the drilling, and continued operation of said well, a combined single limit
insurance blanket liability policy for five million dollars ($5,000,000) with
the City named as an additional insured thereon.
         B.   The petitioner shall indemnify the City from all damages, loss,
or liability of whatever nature or kind caused by or arising out of the
erection of, maintenance, or use of said well.
      (5)   Drilling procedures.
         A.   The well shall be constructed and operated in accordance with the
permits issued by the State Department of Natural Resources, except for any of
the conditions herein which are additional or more restrictive.
         B.   The petitioner shall notify the Fire Chief, the Ward
Councilperson, and the Building Department at least ten days prior to the
commencement of drilling.
         C.   All wells shall be drilled with "mud", a liquid combined with
certain solids. A blowout preventor (BOP) stack shall be required on the well
drilled, including a minimum of one pipe ram or hydril with a subsurface check
valve, and the BOP shall be tested at the well site prior to the start of
drilling.
         D.   All waste substances shall be removed from the well site via tank
truck and deposited at state-approved dump sites. The annular disposal of brine
on the site shall be prohibited.
         E.   When the drilling is completed and the site restored, the Fire
Chief, Building Department, and City Council shall be notified for an
inspection.
         F.   The reserve pit used to contain the brine, mud cuttings, and
other waste material accumulated during the drilling period, shall be filled
immediately upon the completion of the drilling.
         G.   All flammable and combustible liquids from the producing well
shall be stored in underground tanks and all liquids shall be removed from the
tank by tank trucks.
         H.   No driller/permittee, without a permit from the Fire Department,
shall detonate explosive devices, other than the process known as "perforate,"
or perform the process called "fracturing," between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and
7:00 a.m. There shall be no cable tool drilling allowed in the City. All
operations shall be conducted in such a manner as to eliminate, as far as
practical, dust, noise, vibration, and noxious odors.
      (6)   Schedule. The petitioner shall include a statement of the proposed
schedule, listing when the drilling is expected to begin and to be completed,
when the driveway or access road is to be installed and a tentative schedule of
fencing and landscaping.
      (7)   Access roads. 
         A.   All access roads used for ingress and egress to the drilling
site, including, but not limited to, roads leading to tanks or wellheads shall
be concrete or asphalt and be of sufficient width (minimum of 18 feet) and
improved to permit access by emergency vehicles.
         B.   All access to the well site shall be limited to the access road.
         C.   Any debris shall be removed from City streets immediately.
      (8)   Tanks, battery, well head. and sales lines.
         A.   A tank battery shall be located a minimum of 500 feet from the
closest residential property line.
         B.   A tank battery shall be located a minimum of 100 feet from lakes,
streams, rivers, or other large water bodies.
         C.   All tank batteries shall be located a minimum of 100 feet from
public rights-of-way.
         D.   All storage tanks and other equipment located above ground shall
be painted in such shades of dark green as will minimize the visual
obtrusiveness of the equipment. The contents of each storage tank or tank
battery shall be identified in eight inch high letters on the tank in a color
distinct from their background.
         E.   A well head and all storage tanks shall be located a minimum of
500 feet from residential property lines, churches, schools, day-care centers,
public parks, playgrounds, auditoriums, public libraries, shopping centers, or
any other public building which may be used as a place of public assembly.
         F.   The pump jack shall be electrically powered.
         G.   All sales lines from the tank battery shall be permanently marked
for their entire length at a maximum interval of 200 feet between markers.
         H.   Brine tanks shall extend no higher than eight (8) feet from
grade, and, if necessary, shall be recessed in order to meet this requirement.
         I.   All equipment to be used at the well and site shall be maintained
in good operating condition.
         J.   The property owner and operator shall consent to provide
unrestricted access to the well head and tank batteries, to the Fire Chief, the
Building Department, Mayor and City Council for purposes of inspection until
the well is abandoned and the site restored.
      (9)   Plugging of a well. All abandoned oil or gas wells must be plugged
in the manner prescribed by Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509, and Highland Heights Code
Section
733.06, and by this section and shall be done as required by the laws of the
State.
      (10)   Services fee. 
         A.   A fee of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) which is
distinct from the two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) permit
application fee, shall be paid to the City at the time of permit application to
defray the cost of services included, but not limited to, the following:
            1.   Review permit and inspection by the Fire Chief.
            2.   Review of the restoration and planting plan.
         B.   An annual permit and inspection fee of two hundred and fifty
dollars ($250.00) shall be paid to the Fire Department to defray the cost of a
yearly inspection to ensure proper maintenance of all well facilities and site
conditions.
         C.   Council and the Planning and Zoning Commission shall have the
authority, in the course of consideration of the application for a permit and
in the course of periodic inspections of the well, to require the applicant or
certificate holder, as the case may be, to submit evidence both of the
producer's or contractor's qualifications and experience in oil and gas well
operations and/or the condition and maintenance of the equipment and
appurtenances at the well and well site.
      (11)   Performance bond.  To insure the landscaping on the approved
plans, a performance bond shall be placed with the Building Department at one
hundred percent (100%) of the estimated cost of the approved landscaping.
      (12)   Well abandonment. 
         A.   In the event that a well is abandoned, the petitioner must
provide a written notification to the Building Department before the well is
abandoned and equipment removed. All petitioners shall be required to pull and/
or plug a well site on abandonment, remove all aboveground appurtenances,
return the ground to its original grade and condition, and follow any other
rules and regulations promulgated by any department or division of the state
relative to pulling, plugging, or abandoning oil or gas wells. "Abandonment"
means any action or inaction by the applicant, contractor, owner, or other
person which results in a producing well not being operated for at least one
year as defined in Section
733.01 of these regulations, or results in any drilling operation for a new oil
or gas well being halted, stopped, or otherwise suspended for 60 days.
         B.   All abandoned oil or gas wells must be plugged in the manner
prescribed by Ohio Revised Code 1509, and Highland Heights Code Section
733.06 and all well sites shall be returned to predrilling condition.
         C.   After proper plugging, all well sites shall be returned to pre-
drilling condition.
         D.   The planning staff, the City Planning and Zoning Commission, and
Council, when studying a permit application shall be guided by the development
conditions listed in this Zoning Code for the particular use and area districts
in which it is proposed. The petitioner may be required to post a performance
bond to assure compliance with the conditions specified by the Commission and
Council.
      (13)   Variance. The Planning and Zoning Commission may permit exceptions
to any of the provisions in this chapter if the applicant meets the
requirements of an unduly burdensome hardship, and other requirements pursuant
to law, unless such exception falls within the authority of the Ohio Department
of Natural Resources, Division of Oil and Gas.
         (Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.12 PUBLIC NOTICE AND HEARING BY PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   The City Planning and Zoning Commission shall hold a public hearing on each
application for a permit. Before holding this hearing, the Commission shall
give public notice at least ten days before the date of such hearing.
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.13 RECOMMENDATION TO PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   The Building Commissioner and Fire Chief shall investigate the permit
application prior to the City Planning and Zoning Commission's public hearing
and shall recommend its approval, modification, or denial. This recommendation
shall be written and transmitted to the Commission, Applicant, City Council,
and available to concerned citizens at least one week before the required
public hearing. If the recommendation is not transmitted to the Commission,
petitioner, City Council, and available to concerned citizens at least one week
before the required public hearing, the matter shall not be heard until the
next scheduled meeting of the Planning and Zoning Commission. (Ord. 16-2000.
Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.14 RECOMMENDATION BY PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION.
   Following public notice and hearing, the City Planning and Zoning Commission
shall take action on the Application for a Permit. Such action shall be in the
form of a notice recommending to Council that the petition be granted or
granted in part, be modified or not be granted. The Commission shall, on taking
action, submit its recommendations and those of the Building Commission to
Council. The Commission shall be permitted a reasonable time to consider the
petition, but Council may require the Commission to transmit its recommendation
within 60 days from the date of the request. If the Commission fails to act
within the time aforesaid, it shall be deemed to have recommended that the
petition be approved and submitted.
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.15 HEARING BY COUNCIL.
   Council shall schedule a public hearing on the permit application. Such
hearing shall include presentation of the recommendations by the Planning and
Zoning Commission, the Building Commissioner, and the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.16 NOTICE OF PUBLIC HEARING.
   Council shall give public notice of the public hearing required by Highland
Heights Code Section
 733.15 not less than 15 days before the date of the required hearings. The
Clerk of Council shall send, by first class mail, at least 15 days before the
day of the public hearing, written notice of the time, place and nature of the
public hearing to all owners and residents of property within, contiguous to,
and directly across the street from the property involved in the proposed
conditional use. This written notice shall be sent to the owners at their
addresses appearing in the County Auditor's current tax list or the County
Treasurer's mailing list, and to the residents at their addresses appearing in
the current City directory. The failure of delivery of the written notice sent
by the Clerk shall not invalidate any such permit.
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.17 ACTION BY COUNCIL.
   After the public hearing required by Section
 733.15, and after receipt of the recommendation of the Planning and Zoning
Commission, Council shall either adopt or deny the recommendation of the City
Planning and Zoning Commission or adopt some modification thereof. Council may
prescribe appropriate conditions and safeguards in conformity with this Zoning
Code, and a violation of any such conditions and safeguards, when made a part
of the terms under which the petition is granted shall be deemed a violation of
this Zoning Code. If warranted, the Council shall instruct the Building
Commissioner to issue a permit.
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.18 TIME LIMITATION.
   Any permit granted by Council, shall remain valid for a period of one year
from the date of its issuance. If actual drilling of the well is not initiated
within the one year period, from the date of issuance, the permit shall
automatically expire and terminate without further action of Council or
notification of grantee, provided, however, that the grantee may apply to
Council for an extension not to exceed three (3) months upon the payment of a
nonrefundable fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) which shall be utilized by
the City in processing the extension request. The cessation of the drilling
operation for six months, without extension, shall operate to terminate and
cancel the permit, and the well shall be deemed abandoned. Thereafter, no
person shall drill or operate any such well within the City without issuance of
another permit. (Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.19 SURETY BOND REQUIREMENT.
   The applicant for a permit shall be required to post a surety bond or cash
in lieu of bond in the bond in the amount of twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00) to assure compliance with the conditions specified by the
Commission and Council and to insure the faithful performance of all of the
laws, rules and regulations of the City. It shall be approved by the Law
Director. (Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.20 LIMITATIONS.
   Regardless of whether an appropriate permit has been obtained from the Chief
of the Division of Oil and Gas of the State Department of Natural Resources,
pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509 and/or Building Commissioner pursuant to
this chapter, no person, firm or corporation shall:
   (a)   Drill a new gas or oil well in any zoning district other than a P-C-
M District; or
   (b)   Drill a new gas or oil well within the confines of any cemetery; or
   (c)   Drill with other than "a quiet drilling rig" utilizing a double
muffler system; or
   (d)   Drill a gas or oil well within 500 feet of a residential property
line, church, school, day care center, public park or playground, auditorium,
public library, shopping center, or any other public building used as a place
for public assembly.
   (e)   Drill a gas or oil well within 100 feet of a lake, river, stream or
other large body of water.
   (f)   Drill a gas or oil well unless a "blow-out preventer" is utilized on
the drilling rig.
   (g)   Drill a gas or oil well on an area of less than 40 contiguous acres
per well.
      (Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.21 NUISANCES PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall drill, construct, reopen, convert, plug
back, plug, use, operate, maintain, repair, abandon or remove waste materials
from any oil or gas well within the limits of the City in such a manner as to
be injurious, noxious, offensive or dangerous to the health, safety, welfare,
comfort or property of individuals or of the public.
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.22 ODORIZATION.
   No person, firm or corporation shall operate or maintain for its own use and
benefit, a gas or oil well without meeting all state and federal regulations
regarding odorization
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.23 TIME OF DRILLING.
   Drilling a well within the City shall only be permitted between November 15
and March 15. Any drilling of oil or gas wells after March 15 and before
November 15 is prohibited unless all property owners who have received
notification of such proposed drilling pursuant to Highland Heights Code
Section
 733.11(a)(2)C.5., hereof who are located adjacent to, or within a 1000 foot
radius of the proposed location for the wellhead and tanks agree, in writing,
to such drilling.
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
   733.24 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation who violates or fails to comply with, any
provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than one thousand five
hundred dollars ($1,500.00). Each day's violation of any provision of this
chapter shall constitute a separate offense. The Law Director is further
authorized to seek injunctive relief against any violation of this Chapter or
of any amendment hereto in a proper court of law.
(Ord. 16-2000. Passed 9-26-00.)
CHAPTER 735
Street and Sidewalk Vendors
735.01    Definitions.
735.02   Sales prohibited.
735.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Solicitors and canvassers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
717
   735.01 DEFINITIONS.
    For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
    (a)    "Motor vehicle" means any vehicle used for the displaying, storing
or transporting of articles offered for sale by a vendor which is required to
be licensed and registered by the Ohio Department of Highway Safety, Bureau of
Motor Vehicles.
    (b)    "Stand" means any table, showcase, bench, rack, pushcart, wagon or
any other wheeled vehicle or device which may be moved without the assistance
of a motor and which is not required to be licensed and registered by the Ohio
Department of Highway Safety, Bureau of Motor Vehicles, used for the
displaying, storing or transporting of articles offered for sale by a vendor.
    (c)    "Vendor" means any person engaged in the selling, or offering for
sale, of food, beverages or merchandise on the public streets, sidewalks or
public park lands from a stand or motor vehicle or from his person.
      (Ord. 46-1988. Passed 6-14-88.)
   735.02 SALES PROHIBITED.
   No vendor shall operate on any public street, sidewalk or public park land
within the City.
(Ord. 46-1988. Passed 6-14-88.)
   735.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord. 46-1988. Passed 6-14-88.)
CHAPTER 737
Video Service Providers
737.01   Fees.
   737.01 FEES.
   (a)   Council hereby establishes a VSP Fee that is calculated by applying a
VSP Fee Percentage of three percent (3%) to the video service provider’s gross
revenues as defined in Section 1332.32(B) of the Video Law. All video service
providers and cable television operators providing video service in the City
shall apply the VSP Fee Percentage against gross revenues as defined in the
Video Law.
   (b)   The VSP Fee shall be paid by each video service provider providing
service in the City on a quarterly basis but not sooner than forty-five (45)
nor later than sixty (60) days after the end of each calendar quarter.
   (c)   The Mayor is authorized and directed to provide any video service
provider with notice of the VSP Fee Percentage as determined by Council, which
notice shall be given by certified mail, upon receipt of notice from such video
service provider that it will begin providing video service in the City
pursuant to a State-issued video service authorization.
(Ord. 22-2008. Passed 9-9-08.)

CHAPTER 905
Street Excavations
905.01    Permit required.
905.02   Conditions precedent to permit issuance.
905.03   Manner of work and restoration.
905.04   Enforcement and damages.
905.05   Chapter exceptions.
905.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to establish and care for streets - see Ohio R.C. 715.19, 717.01,
723.01
      Openings by municipality - see Ohio R.C. 723.02
      Sprinkling - see Ohio R.C. 723.16 et seq.
      Surface treatment - see Ohio R.C. 723.23, 723.31
      Excavation liability - see Ohio R.C. 723.49 et seq.
      Changing established grade - see Ohio R.C. 727.07
      Digging, excavating and piling earth on streets - see Ohio R.C. 5589.10
      Street excavations in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1167.07(a)
      Street opening permit fees - see BLDG.
1311.14
      Right-of-way improvements - see BLDG.
1311.21
   905.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall make or cause to be made any opening or
excavation in the paved or unpaved portion of any dedicated street in the
Municipality without having first obtained a permit therefor in accordance with
Section
905.02.
(Ord. 493-1955. Passed 11-28-55.)
   905.02 CONDITIONS PRECEDENT TO PERMIT ISSUANCE.
   The Building Commissioner shall issue a permit to applicants who comply with
the following conditions:
   (a)    File a written signed application which specifies the location and
size of the opening or excavation, the reason therefor, the time frame and
schedule of the work planned and, time within which it will be restored and
repaired, the name and address of the applicant, and the name and address of
the person, firm or corporation that does the work;
   (b)   All contractors must be registered with the Building Department in
accordance with Chapter
1313;
   (c)   A completed application must meet the approval of and be signed by the
City Engineer or the Service Director or their designee prior to issuance of a
permit;
   (d)    Pay the fee(s) and post the cash bond and deposit(s) required by
Section
1311.14.
      (Ord. 3-2011. Passed 3-22-11.)
   905.03 MANNER OF WORK AND RESTORATION.
   Openings and excavations in dedicated streets, rights of way, and/or public
easements shall be made and restored as required by the City Engineer, the
Service Director or their designee and in the following manner:
   (a)    All openings and excavations and the backfilling and restoration
thereof and all work zones shall comply with all laws, guidelines and practices
as set forth in the most recent version(s) of; the Ohio Revised Code; the Ohio
Department of Transportation (ODOT) Construction and Materials Manual; the Ohio
Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices (OMUTCD); the Cuyahoga County Uniform
Standards for Sewerage Improvements; and the Ohio Utility Protection Service
(OUPS) except as allowed or directed by the City Engineer and/or the Service
Director or their designee and/or in the case of maintenance of traffic, by any
member of the Police Department.
   (b)   All streets, public property, and lawfully installed improvements
therein which are disturbed by the permittee’s activity shall be restored to
the Municipality’s satisfaction in the time frame prescribed by the
Municipality, or if not prescribed by the Municipality, as soon as possible (in
no circumstances more than thirty (30) days from the date of completion of
construction) by the permittee, at its expense, to, at a minimum, the condition
which existed prior to construction, all to the Municipality’s satisfaction. In
the event replacement and restoration of the area is not completed within
thirty (30) days or as soon as reasonably possible, the Municipality may, upon
written notice to the permittee, complete any necessary work at the sole
expense of the permittee. The Municipality may utilize the proceeds of the bond
provided for in Section
1311.14 to restore any disturbed area where the permittee fails to timely
undertake or complete such restoration.
      (Ord. 3-2011. Passed 3-22-11.)
   905.04 ENFORCEMENT AND DAMAGES.
   The Director of Law is hereby authorized to take action to enjoin the
violation of this chapter and to recover damages suffered by the Municipality
because of any violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 493 -1955. Passed 11-28-55.)
   905.05 CHAPTER EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to excavations made by a governmental agency
and persons acting for such agency.
(Ord. 493-1955. Passed 11-28-55.)
   905.99 PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or any provision of
the permit granted shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord. 3-2011. Passed 3-22-11.)
CHAPTER 909
Sidewalk Construction
909.01    Permit application information.
909.02   Permit fee to cover two inspections.
909.03   Fee for line and grade settings.
909.04   Inspection and approval by Engineer.
909.05   Construction of sidewalks required by City; permit fees; effective
date.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Construction or repair at owner's expense - see Ohio R.C.
         729.01 et seq.
      Notice to construct or repair sidewalks - see Ohio R.C.
         729.03 et seq.
      Sidewalk obstructions; damage or injury - see GEN. OFF.
521.04 
      Sidewalks in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1167.08 
   909.01 PERMIT APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   An application for a permit shall be required of an owner of property who
desires to construct a sidewalk improvement in relation to his property within
the public right of way. Such application shall contain the name and address of
the applicant, a brief description of the improvement to be made and the
approximate date of completion of such improvement.
(Ord. 13-1962. Passed 4-10-62.)
   909.02 PERMIT FEE TO COVER TWO INSPECTIONS.
   Permit fees shall be required as set forth in Section
1311.131(b) herein.
(Ord. 44-2001. Passed 11-13-01.)
   909.03 FEE FOR LINE AND GRADE SETTINGS.
   Where it is determined by the Engineer that it is necessary to establish
line and grade settings, an additional fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) is
hereby established. Such fee shall be paid at the time that application is
made, and is in addition to the permit fee as provided for in Section
909.02.
(Ord. 37-1986. Passed 6-10-86.)
   909.04 INSPECTION AND APPROVAL BY ENGINEER.
   Prior to the issuance of a permit by the Service Director, the Engineer
shall inspect the premises to be improved, shall determine the grade level and
location of such sidewalk improvement, and shall provide the applicant with
specifications for the construction of such improvement. The Engineer shall
periodically inspect the construction of the sidewalk improvement, and shall,
upon its completion, signify his acceptance of the improvement by written
statement to the Service Director. (Ord. 13-1962. Passed 4-10-62.)
   909.05 CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS REQUIRED BY CITY; PERMIT FEES; EFFECTIVE
DATE.
   When the City declares its intent to construct sidewalks on existing
residential premises and to assess the cost therefor against the abutting
property owner, whether in whole or in part, then any owner of property who
elects to construct his own sidewalk to avoid such assessment shall be charged
only one dollar ($1.00) for the permit fee required by Section
909.02 and shall not be charged the line and grade setting fee required by
Section
909.03. This section shall be retroactive to July 15, 1982 and the owner of any
residential property who, under the circumstances governed by this section,
elected to construct his own sidewalk to avoid an assessment and who paid any
amount in excess of the fee required by this section
shall be entitled to a refund of any amount paid by him in excess of the fee
required by this section. Application for such refund shall be made to the
Building Commissioner at any time following the effective date of this section.

(Ord. 4-1983. Passed 1-25-83.)
CHAPTER 910
Sidewalk and Apron Maintenance and Repair
910.01   Inspection of sidewalk and apron by Building Commissioner.
910.02   Notice to owner concerning necessary construction.
910.03   Publication of notice.
910.04   Notice contents.
910.05   Resolution of necessity.
910.06   Notice of estimate of assessment; objection.
910.07   Billing owner of abutting property; date bill payable.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Duty to keep sidewalks in repair and clean - see GEN. OFF.
521.06
      Sidewalk construction - see S. & P.S. Ch.
909
      Driveways - see BLDG. Ch.
1323
   910.01 INSPECTION OF SIDEWALK AND APRON BY BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
   The City Building Commissioner shall inspect and make a survey of thirty-
three percent (33%) of all sidewalks and aprons in the City, on or before April
15 of each calendar year for three successive years, skipping the fourth year,
and then recommencing the inspection process in the succeeding calendar year.
Thereupon, he shall make a record of all sidewalks and aprons which do not
conform to this chapter and shall obtain an estimate of the cost of repairs
required from the Contractor Engineer. The City Building Commissioner shall
thereupon report their condition to the Clerk of Council, who shall notify in
writing the owner or agent of the owner of the property abutting on any
sidewalk or apron which should be repaired instructing owner or agent to repair
or construct the same within a reasonable time, but not less than thirty days
after the service of such notice. On failure of such owner to repair or
construct such sidewalk or apron, the Building Commissioner shall report to
Council such information as Council may require for further action. Should the
owner within the time stated in the notice fail to construct grade repair or
replace the sidewalk or apron in accordance with the notice, the Building
Commissioner shall proceed to cause the work to be done by contract and the
cost thereof to the property owner, and if necessary the cost shall be
assessed, in accordance with this chapter. The Director shall, in addition to
the above, order sidewalks or aprons to be constructed or repaired when it is
deemed necessary for public safety and welfare.
(Ord. 7-2002. Passed 4-23-02.)
   910.02 NOTICE TO OWNER CONCERNING NECESSARY CONSTRUCTION.
   Whenever the Building Commissioner finds that any sidewalk or apron should
be constructed, repaired or replaced or is not free from nuisance, he shall
notify the Clerk of Council, who shall notify the owner of the abutting
property, in writing, to have the necessary construction, reconstruction or
repair made. This notice shall include a showing of the Resolution of Necessity
and the location of the sidewalk and apron area, the nature of the
construction, grading, repairing or replacement necessary, the materials to be
used and the estimated costs thereof. Such notice shall be served on the owner
or his agent in the manner provided by law for the service of summons in civil
actions. For the purpose of such service, any person charged with the
collection of rents or the payment of taxes on the property or having general
control of rents or the payment of taxes in any way, is considered the agent of
the owner. (Ord. 26-1993. Passed 8-23-94.)
   910.03 PUBLICATION OF NOTICE.
   When there is no resident owner in the City or no agent available for
service of notice, or the place of residence of the owner cannot be found, the
Clerk of Council shall have the notice published at least twice in a newspaper
of general circulation in the City.
(Ord. 26-1993. Passed 8-23-94.)
   910.04 NOTICE CONTENTS.
   The notice provided for in Sections
910.02 and
910.03 shall identify the property and give the location of the sidewalk and
apron and the period of time allowed the property owner to have the work done
by private contract.
(Ord. 26-1993. Passed 8-23-94.)
   910.05 RESOLUTION OF NECESSITY.
   When it is deemed necessary by Council to require the construction or repair
of sidewalks within the City by the owners of the lots or land abutting
thereon, Council shall cause an estimate of the cost of such construction or
repair to be prepared, showing the location and dimensions of such sidewalks
and aprons and the specifications for the construction or repair thereof to be
filed in the office of the Clerk of Council. After such estimate of cost has
been filed, as provided in this section, Council may declare the necessity for
the construction or repair of such sidewalks by the adoption of a resolution
which shall:
   (a)   Approve the estimate of cost of the proposed construction or repair on
file as provided by this section;
   (b)   Set forth that such sidewalks shall be constructed or repaired by the
owners of the lots or lands abutting thereon in accordance with the
specifications on file in the office of the Clerk of Council;
   (c)   Set forth the time within which such sidewalks shall be constructed or
repaired by the owners of the lots and lands abutting thereon, which shall not
be less than thirty days from the date of service of notice under Section
910.02 hereof on the owner of the lots or lands; and
   (d)   State that in the event such sidewalks are not constructed or repaired
by the owners of the lots and lands abutting thereon in accordance with the
policy of the City established in this chapter, and within the time prescribed
in the resolution, the City will so construct or repair such sidewalks and
assess the costs thereof against the lots and lands abutting thereon.
   (e)   All concrete work, whether original installation or repair work, for
all sidewalks and aprons in the City shall meet and be governed by the
specifications set forth by the City Engineer.
      (Ord. 26-1993. Passed 8-23-94.)
   910.06 NOTICE OF ESTIMATE OF ASSESSMENTS; OBJECTION.
   (a)   The Clerk of Council shall cause a notice to be published for three
consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the Municipality
stating that a list of estimated assessments has been made and is on file in
the office of the Clerk of Council for the inspection and examination of
persons interested therein.
   (b)   If any person objects to an assessment on such list, he or she shall
file his objection in writing with the Clerk of Council within two weeks after
the expiration of the notice provided in this section.
(Ord. 26-1993. Passed 8-23-94.)
   910.07 BILLING OWNER OF ABUTTING PROPERTY; DATE BILL PAYABLE.
   (a)   Upon completion by the City of any sidewalk construction,
reconstruction and/or repair as provided in Section
910.05, the owner of the abutting property, or his agent shall be billed for
the cost and expense of the work. Such bills shall include:
      (1)   A charge for administrative costs of fifteen percent (15%) of the
construction costs; and
      (2)   A financing charge of three percent (3%) of the construction costs.
   (b)   If the costs of remedying the condition are not paid within thirty
days after receipt of a bill from the City, the amount shall become a lien upon
the property to be included in the next tax bill rendered to the property
owners, and shall be collected in the same manner as other taxes against such
property.
(Ord. 26-1993. Passed 8-23-94.)

CROSS REFERENCES
      Compulsory sewer connections - see Ohio R.C. 729.06
      Sewers generally - see Ohio R.C. 729.31 et seq.
      Management and control of sewerage system - see Ohio R.C. 729.50
      Storm sewers in subdivisions - see P. & Z.
1167.07(b)
      Sewer permit fees - see BLDG.
1311.04
      Pool drainage - see BLDG.
1319.06
   913.01 CONSTRUCTION OR RELOCATION PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall construct, install or relocate on
private or public property in the Municipality, a storm sewer ten inches or
more in diameter or appurtenances thereto, drainage ditches, culverts or
bridges, or increase or decrease the size or grade of, or obstruct or
accelerate the natural flow of, any existing natural or artificially made
watercourse or drainage ditch without having first obtained a permit therefor
from the Building Commissioner as provided for herein. (Ord. 535-1956. Passed
9-10-56.)
 
   913.02 APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   Application for a permit to make any improvement listed in Section
913.01 shall be made in writing and contain the following information:
   (a)    Names and addresses of all owners of land involved;
   (b)    Name and address of the applicant;
   (c)    Names and addresses of persons performing the work, and
   (d)    A statement of the reason for making the improvement specified.
      (Ord. 535-1956. Passed 9-10-56.)
   913.03 DEPOSIT; REFUND MINUS PERMIT FEE AND COSTS .
   The applicant shall deposit with his application a certified check payable
to the Municipality or cash in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00), which
shall be used to pay the Engineer for his services in approving the plans for
the improvement, and inspecting and approving construction. Any unexpended sum
shall be returned to the applicant after final approval by the Engineer, except
for five dollars ($5.00), which shall be the permit fee.
(Ord. 535-1956. Passed 9-10-56.)
   913.04 PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS; SUBMISSION AND APPROVAL.
   (a)    The applicant shall also submit with his application a set of plans
and specifications for the improvement which the Building Commissioner shall
forward to the Engineer.
   (b)    The Engineer shall approve such improvement plans and specifications
if he finds that they comply with the applicable specifications set forth in
the Subdivision Regulations (Chapter
1161 et seq. of the Codified Ordinances), or where inapplicable, that they
comply with accepted engineering principles and standards, and shall not be
detrimental or injurious to the property of any other person affected thereby.
(Ord. 535-1956. Passed 9-10-56.)
   913.05 PERMIT ISSUANCE AFTER APPROVAL.
   The Building Commissioner shall issue the permit upon receiving the
certificate of the Engineer's approval if the applicant has otherwise complied
with this chapter.
(Ord. 535-1956. Passed 9-10-56.)
   913.06 COMPLIANCE WITH APPROVED PLANS.
   No improvement shall be constructed, installed or made contrary to the plans
and specifications as approved by the Engineer.
(Ord . 535-1956. Passed 9-10-56.)
   913.07 CHAPTER APPLICATION.
   This chapter shall not apply to improvements made as part of a subdivision
pursuant to the Subdivision Regulations (Chapter
1161 et seq. of the Codified Ordinances) or made pursuant to a contract with
the Municipality or by Cuyahoga County. No permit shall be issued pursuant to
this chapter if to do so would allow avoidance of the provisions of the
Subdivision Regulations (Chapter
1161 et seq.).
(Ord. 535-1956. Passed 9-10-56.)
   913.08 VIOLATIONS AT EXPENSE OF VIOLATOR.
   All violations of Sections
913.01 or
913.07 shall be enjoined by the Municipality and such unlawful improvement
shall be removed at his own expense by the person constructing, installing,
making or causing the same.
(Ord. 535-1956. Passed 9-10-56.)
   913.09 APPEAL TO PLANNING COMMISSION.
   Applicants denied permits applied for under Section
913.01 may appeal from the refusal of the Building Commissioner to the Planning
and Zoning Commission.
(Ord. 535-1956. Passed 9-10-56.)
   913.10 BUILDING PERMITS FOR PREMISES ABUTTING DRAINAGE DITCHES.
   No building permit shall be issued for the construction of a building on a
lot which abuts a public road on which is located a roadside drainage ditch,
unless the plans and specifications submitted for approval provide for the
construction of extensions of private driveways over roadside drainage ditches
in the manner specified in Section
913.12, or unless the applicant agrees in writing to comply with Section
913.12.
(Ord . 459-1954. Passed 12-13-54.)
   913.11 NOTICE OF NONCOMPLIANCE.
   The Service Director is hereby authorized and directed to inspect, from time
to time, the private driveway extensions over roadside ditches. If he finds,
upon the advise of the Building Commissioner, that such an extension is not
constructed as specified in Section
913.12, then he shall give written notice to the owner of the property to which
such extension leads, notifying him of such improper construction. Such owner
shall, within thirty days thereafter, either restore such roadside ditch to its
original condition before such driveway extension was constructed, or
reconstruct such driveway extension in the manner specified in Section
913.12.
(Ord. 459-1954. Passed 12-13-54.)
   913.12 CULVERT REQUIREMENTS; INSPECTION.
   (a)    Whenever a property owner constructs a private driveway extension
over the unpaved portion of a public road from his property line to the paved
portion of such road, and such unpaved portion has on it a roadside drainage
ditch, he shall provide for the unobstructed flow of drainage water in such
ditch by installing a culvert under such driveway extension to the following
specifications:
      (1)    Inside diameter to be at least twelve inches;
      (2)    Length to be at least sixteen feet; and
      (3)    Material to be either concrete or corrugated metal pipe.
   (b)    The Service Director may require an inside diameter no greater than
forty-eight inches or a length no greater than forty feet, or may require or
permit construction to be of material other than concrete or corrugated metal
if, in his opinion, the size of the ditch or driveway or other circumstances so
require. (Ord . 459-1954. Passed 12-13-54.)
   (c)    The Service Director is hereby authorized and directed to inspect all
culverts within the City constructed pursuant to the requirements of this
section, such inspection to take place during the month of May of each calendar
year. If such inspection discloses that any such culvert is bent, broken or
obstructed, so as to impede the flow of drainage water in the ditch in which
the same is installed, he shall give written notice to the owner of the
property to which the driveway extension over the culvert leads, notifying him
of such obstruction. Such owner shall, within thirty days thereafter, repair or
replace the culvert, so as to provide for unobstructive flow of drainage water
in the ditch in which the culvert is installed.
(Ord. 23-1975. Passed 8-26-75.)
   913.13 APPEAL TO PLANNING COMMISSION.
   Owners who are refused building permits by the Building Commissioner and
owners who receive notice to restore or reconstruct from the Service Director
may appeal such decision to the Planning and Zoning Commission within twenty
days after such refusal or notice. The Commission shall, after hearing all the
evidence, affirm, reverse or modify such decision. An owner shall not be
entitled to apply for a writ of mandamus or other order to any court unless all
the administrative remedies provided in this chapter are first exhausted.
(Ord. 459-1954. Passed 12-13-54.)
   913.14 NONCOMPLIANCE; COUNCIL MAY AUTHORIZE WORK; RECOVERY OF COSTS.
   If an owner who is granted a building permit fails to comply with Section
913.12 or any order made pursuant to it within sixty days after construction is
begun, or if an owner is notified by the Service Director and fails to comply
with Section
913.12, or any order made pursuant thereto within thirty days after such notice
or order, then Council may by resolution order the culvert constructed or
reconstructed by the Municipality. Council may either assess the cost thereof
over a period of not more than two years against the property to which the
driveway extension leads or it may direct the Director of Law to bring an
action against the owner of such property in any court of competent
jurisdiction to recover such costs.
(Ord. 459-1954. Passed 12-13-54.)
   913.15 INJUNCTION AUTHORIZED TO FORCE COMPLIANCE.
   The Director of Law is hereby authorized and directed to bring suit in the
name of the Municipality for a mandatory injunction or other relief to compel
owners who are granted a building permit to comply with Section
913.12, or any order made pursuant thereto and to compel owners who are
notified by the Service Director to comply with Section
913.12 or any order made pursuant thereto.
(Ord. 459-1954. Passed 12-13-54.)
   913.16 REMEDIES NOT EXCLUSIVE.
   The remedies provided in this chapter are not intended to prevent the
Municipality from pursuing such other remedies as are otherwise authorized by
statute or ordinance.
(Ord. 459-1954. Passed 12-13-54.)
   913.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter or fails to comply with any
provision of this chapter or any order issued pursuant thereto shall be fined
not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day's continued violation
shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 459-1954. Passed 12-13-54; Ord. 535-1956. Passed 9-10-56.)
